content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												Sometimes, you need a game that's frenetic, fast paced and full of chaos.  You need some escapism so you get away from the humdrum of your day job by pretending to be some beefcake named Slab Rockhard blast some bugs to bits with your AK - 22.  Other times though, you need to come home, kick back, crack a brewski and chill out.  Take it easy, shoot some pool like a pro and relax.  That's what you have Pool Nation for.  It's zero pressure, it's zero chaos. It's 100% cool, daddy-o.  It's got some great physics too, so you can shoot pool and feel like a king. Because some times, you need to come home and pretend that you're a slick mo-fo pool shark.  Because if you tried to play pool in the real world, people would realize you're a 40 year old dork in dad jeans try his damnedest to look cool. I uh...that may have gotten too personal.

number of helpful: 54 of 62 people (87%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												Pool Nation isn't a perfect pool game, but it's a huge step up from what's come before. If you're not already a billiards fan, Pool Nation won't make you one. Conversely, for those dying to scratch the billiards itch, Pool Nation is sure to satisfy. An entertaining, highly varied and technically excellent pool game, even if lacking in innovation or new elements for its genre.With Pool Nation you'll get a pooling experience that you've never had before. The simulator delivers several game modes and a lot of options to choose from. Every kind of shot that you can imagine is possible to make in the game and because of that you can truly speak of a great simulator. Another big plus are the graphics, which are truly stunning for a low budget title. Overall, Cherry Pop Games's first endeavour has left us with a fantastic billiards game featuring stunning visuals, great audio and even better physics. The lengthy, albeit difficult career mode, will give you plenty of play time but perhaps for the wrong reasons. If you're looking for a realistic, stylish, and fun billiards game, Pool Nation is the cream of the crop.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												Pool Nation is one of my favorite games on Steam. The solid gameplay and controls were not enough for Cherry Pop Games, they went ahead and added some beautiful locations each offered during day, sunset, and neon lit night time. The amazing soundtrack gets you in the mood whether you want to relax or get pumped. The game modes for single player include 3ball, 8ball, 9ball, endurance, golf, killer, rotation, speed, and straight. In addition, you can play online versus friends in a friendly match or choose to be competitive in tournament mode. The most recent update includes "box of tricks" free of charge, allowing you to create a custom trick shot that you can share with the world. This game is the complete package.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												Pool Nation is a great pool simulator that will make you feel like a hustler once you master all the different trick shots. Lots of different game modes like 9-ball, 8-ball, endurance, and tournaments. Plus you can play online versus friends. The game offers good graphics, although they can be a little bit on the shiny side. The cue control system is mostly user friendly even though sometimes it can feel like a chore to set up a trick shot just right. Straight shots are extremely intuitive and the angle assistance makes it really easy to sink shots. Although bank shots and combos aren't so straightforward.This is the first real pool game that I have played on the PC and quite frankly I wouldn't be surprised if it was the last. I just don't know how it can get any better. The game trailers and screenshots really sold me before my purchase and the game certainly has not disappointed--really well done. The only blemish is that it occassionally crashes.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
 “8-Ball - Corner Pocket” ‘Pool Nation’ is a fun, polished Billiards simulator and a bargain at its $1 pricetag (Steam Fall Sale 2014). Released as the maiden offering from Cherry Pop Games, it’s gorgeous visuals, multiple game modes, lengthy campaign and lots of unlockables will keep Pool fans coming back for more.   Campaign | Gameplay: Gamers have the choice of playing standard 8-ball or variations like 9-ball, Rotation, Endurance, Sudden Death etc across a variety of visually stunning locations / pool halls. A lengthy campaign mode (against AI opponents) allows you to perfect your game and strive toward numerous unlockables including new locations, pool table decals, new ball styles and cue styles. Additionally, the online mode allows you to match up with friends or other online players in single matches, Tournaments or King of the Hill events. Multiple difficulty levels (from Novice to Pro), a spot on physics engine, responsive controls, and a great soundtrack make this the best Pool game to date.Flaws: In considering its biggest issues – 1. Game Stability is poor (Tabbing to windows results in an insta-crash) and 2. Online Gaming is largely dead (Bring your own friends). Additionally, the developers have pushed the previously promised ‘Trick Shot’ mode to the next release, and the lack of Co-op play is disappointing as well.Overall, ‘Pool Nation’ is the best conception of a Billiards game to date and fans of the real game will find this a fun, polished distraction. But, even ardent fans soon realize that Pool without the smoky basement rooms, uneven cues, pitchers of beer, chatty girls, side-bets and bar-room trash talk, is a somewhat hollow experience. Recommended on Sale (Best played with Friends) - Rated (7/10) Want More Recommendations? Make sure to click the 'Follow' button on our Curator Page (Link Attached) to get the latest reviews updated directly onto your Activity Feed. Link:  'Game Syndicate - Curator Page'

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												An excellent pool simulator with great physics and excellent controls (both M+WASD and gamepad work very well). It has an extensive career mode, free mode, fun challenges with unusual game types, tournaments, and online multi-player mode. Pool Nation is gorgeous - right down the the details in the fabric. The only negative in presentation is that your opponents are disembodied as are you; no physical presentation of the players in the game. There are also no spectators. You play in these gorgeous modern venues with seating for dozens or even hundreds, but they are entirely empty.As someone who has had a slate pool table in my home for most of my life, I find this a compelling simulation and well worth the few dollars of the asking price.

AUDIOElectronicaVISUALDazzlingDIFFICULTYSharp Learning CurveVIBEChillCRAVINGBilliardsON SALEDiscountedPROS: Solid pool simulator with reasonably-dependable multiplayer. Fun single-player tournament mode. Game has a fair amount of complexity not offered in other similar games allowing players to pull off cool shots. CONS: Game has the tendency to occasionally glitch out. Planned features appear to be on an indefinite hiatus, and much-needed updates haven't happened. The developer has switched focus to other projects, so I wouldn't hold my breath for this version to come to full fruition.OVERALL: A fun game to share with friends, and it goes on sale for 1.00-2.00USD rather often. The game seems to have an active community, though it has been hard for me personally to get in touch with players I've reached out to. Hoping to see more updates.SCORE:7/10                                                                     Full Review Coming Soon

number of helpful: 18 of 26 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
												Right off the bat, one thing that will catch your attention is the variety of game types.  Most billiards games like to focus only on either 8- or 9-ball.  Those games are here, but they do not stop at that.  Along the game, other games like Rotation and Golf are in the mix.  With nine different ways currently available with Snooker and Trick coming soon, there are plenty of ways to play.Another strong point about the game is the controls.  Like in any other pool game, being able to control the cue ball is important.  Most games simply allow you to aim the ball and adjust the power.  Even though most games stop at this, there are more options to offer.  By being able to adjust the angle of the cue stick as well as where on the cue ball to aim, it gives the option of doing jump and swerve shots, something most billiard games leave out.  Additionally, with a full tutorial teaching how to do all of these moves, it does not take long before they become second nature.Beyond all the gameplay details, a nice touch about the game is the amount of customization available.  Even games that try to simulate pro billiards tend to stick to a single, sometimes sponsored look throughout the game.  This one goes beyond the basics.  As soon as you start a game, the highly detailed and moving locals make it feel like you are in what could be a real location.  As you keep progressing, at least a dozen locals, cue sticks, ball sets, and even table decals make it that regardless your taste, there is plenty to see even from a visual standpoint.Once the single-player game is over, there is still more to play.  Through online multiplayer, it is possible to keep playing with others.  It is even possible to create tournaments to learn who the best player is.  However, the one drawback is that there is no local multiplayer mode available.  This means that in order to play with another person in the same room, the two of you must play through a network.  This feels like a major oversight.  A simple hot seat patch would have made that the game could be a great party game.  Even without local multiplayer, this is still a great package that any billiards fan can easily enjoy.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2015
												The difficulties I have with Pool Nation start in the fact that I already know ho to play pool. I will explain: The english in Pool Nation does not accurately represent the way in which a ball would travel with said spin. Top and bottom english when making a cut shot can cause the cue ball to travel more left or right on the deflection, and this is not represented at all.Left/right english isn't actually as useful on a pool table as an amateur might think. I rarely use left/right english in real pool, as top/bottom english can account for most necessary ball control.As I can best explain it: Top and bottom english account most for how the cue ball deflects off the object ball, and left/right english effects the way the cue ball deflects off rails. There is a small amount of effect with left/right on ball deflection, and top/bottom on rail deflection, but it is very slight.This has to do with the fact that the rail is a solid unmovable force, and ball deflection is sympathetic to mass/friction.My previous pool experience makes this game very unintuitive!

content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												Hands down the best Pool game out there. Beautiful textures, great physics and enough variation in games to keep you busy for a while. Best of all it runs great on my old-as-dirt PC.Multiplayer is a blast, especially if you can get a group together for a tournament. The free roaming camera allows for amazingly framed shots when you are brodcasting the game. Your spectators won't get bored!Multiple levels of difficulty are present, and should gbe used if you are looking for a challenge. The novice mode is only good for the first few rounds, as it reveals quite a bit of the ball paths. My only complaint here is that champion mode perhaps reveals too much as well (Cue ball only).Tricks shots are a blast to pull of and never get old. Experimenting with angles and english prove to be highly satisfying. Especially when you pot the winning shot with a knifes edge. Looking forward to the new mode: Box of Tricks, and maybe Trading cards? (wink wink).

												Pool Nation is one of the most polished indie games I ever played. The animations are shiny and smooth, the gameplay is responsive and the physics are realistic. content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
												Pool Nation is one of the most polished indie games of 2013- the animations are shiny and smooth, the gameplay is responsive and the physics are realistic. You won't find yourself screaming at this game for bouncing your balls in the wrong direction, or glitching out and dropping your cue ball through the table. With eleven game modes including tournaments, online play, and single-player endurance mode; as well as a slew of collectables to unlock, Pool Nation has no shortage of goodies to keep gameplay fresh.The single player component revolves primarily around tournaments where you take on AI challengers of ever increasing difficulty. Each match has an associated list of challenges, and completing them unlocks a variety of cosmetic changes like cues and balls. Standard games like 9 ball are present along with more interesting options like Golf, which challenges you to put specific balls into specific pockets. There’s also a time attack style mode, where balls spawn on the table and you have to sink as many as possible in the time limit. There are Free Play, Versus, and Online modes present too, but I had a hard time finding anyone to challenge online.Pool Nation is a great looking game that features bright and shiny graphics that makes each game, literally, feel new and different. There are some good themes on the game's soundtrack, and though the game's controls look difficult to use, they aren't difficult to learn. There are also options that can be easily turned on or off to give players assists in a game including arrows that point at the next balls that need to be hit or arrows that show where a ball will travel when hit. All of these features combine to make an excellent presentation for Pool Nation. But is it fun? In short stints I definitely enjoyed playing the game, but it isn’t the type of thing I’d want to play for hours at a time. Having said that, I think Pool Nation is the kind of experience that would be a hit at a house party. If you’ve been searching far and wide for a Billiards simulator, and don’t have room for an actual table, Pool Nation is probably the solution. The physics are solid, the controls allow for extreme fine tuning of shots, and everything looks super shiny. A few more game types would be welcome, but for $10 Pool Nation is the gold standard in the category.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												Hey guys, thanks for reading my reviews. Let me make this as plain as possible. If you like pool and can find this cheap, check it out. It's not bad at all. I think the controls are better here in many ways than I've seen in previous PC pool games, but what's the game really like? You get nine ball, eight ball, and a few mini-games. There is a trick mode that hasn't been put into the game yet apparently. The humor is painful mostly, but not always bad. Just never very clever or subtle.As for the negative stuff: I think it gets repetitious. It's also buggy. I don't like the AI at all, as it sometimes seems too transparent what's happening in the game. Some of the rounds a really good AI player will goof several times in a row to give me a chance to beat it. Other times it feels like it's cheating to win.  Sometimes the match challenges don't appear to count properly or are too literally applied, and it seems inconsistant with its application of what meets the requirements of a given challenge. For example, I played a match that wanted me to get a 3 ball streak with a jump shot. I got a 4 ball streak with a jump at the end and it didn't count it. The next time I played, it seemed to count it. So I just don't trust the AI at all. Also, some of the designer ball sets that you can unlock confuse me visually because the stripes and solids look too similar to me from a distance. The settings are very colorful, which isn't necessarily bad, but can be VERY loud. Anyway, even though this seems a negative review, it's not meant to be. The devs say they are working to improve it, and if they do I think it has a lot of potential. As it is, if you can get it for a very low price and you like pool, try it. I've enjoyed playing it, but it can be frustrating at times.

												If you like pool, this is your best (and only) option on steam. It looks great and sounds great technically and stylistically. There are nearly no loading times after you start the game, making beginning and playing games as fast as you want it to be. For playing pool itself, there are lots of easy to use but hard to master options for doing more tricky shots. Curve balls, jump balls, bank balls. It's all there and can be executed with serious precision. Even when you knock a ball clean off the table, the satisfying crunch on the floor makes a failed shot sound so sweet.There's really not much that can be done to improve this game. The only trouble I've had with this game is using the replay function and the online multiplayer isn't very active, but the core game is as solid as an 8-ball. If you have any interest in video game pool, this is as good as it gets.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												Pool Nation delivers a solid billiards simulation experience.  It makes the grade in the areas critical to this type of game:  the physics are sound,the shot-making is clean, and there's enough variety in the game types to keep things fresh for a while.  On top of that, the game is downright beautiful.There are some flaws, but nothing game-breaking.  The most glaring (for me, anyway) was that the game feels literally empty.  When shooting, you're shooting in a seemingly deserted hall.  There's no crowd, no opponent squirming in the chair as you knock the balls down.  Speaking of your opponents, while their descriptions are modestly humorous, there's little to differentiate them from one to the next.  At times it feels a bit sterile.  Again, this isn't really game-breaking.  But part of the allure of playing at the bar or hall is the atmosphere, and the game is lacking in that regard.All in all, though, the plusses outweigh the minuses.  If you're a billiards enthusiast, this game is just about value for money at full price and a bargain if you can pick it up on sale.

content:
Posted: February 20
TL;DRA solid arcadey pool game with a variety of modes. Despite the small playerbase and no previously promised snooker mode, I recommend it to any fool pan pool fan, especially on sale.+ User-friendly mechanics+ Gorgeous graphics and flashy gameplay (jump shots, swerve shots, etc.)+ A variety of gamemodes (honourable mention: endurance mode)+ Witty descriptions+ Fitting soundtrack+ Fair AI+ Lots of cues, decals, and ball sets- Small playerbase- No promised snooker mode- Minor bugsREVIEWPool Nation is an arcadey pool simulation game. This one takes the player to the world of fancy lounges, chillout music, and jump shots.The game is very accessible: tutorials are short but cover important basics to get one started. One can also adjust the aiming aid level (novice -> veteran -> pro -> champion -> off) which is a huge plus. Players can test their skills against the AI opponents in VS and Career modes, as well as against other people, and solo in the Endurance mode. The last mode is a time trial and requires quick thinking and precise shots, as the balls spawn faster as the time goes by and when the ball count on the table reaches 24, the game is over.The career mode is divided into two tournaments (9-ball and 8-ball), each with four cups. There are 12 matches in each cup plus a couple of bonus matches in lesser known modes, such as killer, 3-ball, speed pool, and the like. Each of the matches has two optional challenges to complete, for instance finishing a match with a skill shot, a ball streak, etc. Completing certain matches unlocks cosmetics. There are loads of decals, cues, and ball sets to be earned and the only problem is that they seem to reset to default ones every time the game is started. It is a minor issue but worth mentioning nonetheless.This game looks and sounds great. The sounds of cue action combined with jazzy muzaks in the background create a laid-back atmosphere. Sit back, take the weight off your shoulders, and pot the balls like a boss – this game lets one do just that. Furthermore, the AI is fair for the most part and the difficulty curve is not very steep, making the experience very pleasant and virtually rage-free.Overall, I recommend getting this game on sale to any fan of billiards games. While it may not be a realistic simulation and its playerbase may be really small, this game can provide hours of entertainment and satisfy the itch for some pool action. It indeed is a shame that the snooker mode was not delivered, given how much fun this game is.P.S. Sit back, grab a beverage of choice, and read more reviews here: http://steamcommunity.com/id/FinnVArthur/recommended/My curation page: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/FVABot/curation

content:
Posted: May 26, 2014
												The TL;DR: Amazing Pool game for both veterans and beginners. With many game modes(rule sets) and Free Play, local and online multiplayer, and several things to aid beginners, such as aim assist, an interactive tutorial to teach trick shots, and to always have the controls listed on the side of the screen. This, of course, can all be turned off.Great pool game! The main game modes in single player seem to be 8 and 9 Ball Tour Modes, where you play that ruleset against increasingly difficult AI opponents, who have humorous Bios. However they have other game modes/rule sets as Bonus Matches in the tour. Each opponent has 3 Stars you can collect as an added challenge, which can be completed for extra replayability. You get the first star simply by beating the opponent, which will also unlock the next opponent. The other 2 stars are gained by completing the objectives which are different for each opponent, then winning, since even if you complete the objectives, they won't count unless you win the match too. These Challenges range from doing specific trick shots, reaching a certain score, using no flashbacks(feature where you can redo a shot twice per match), etc. There is only one use for stars. Each of the Bonuses Matches are 'linked' to an opponent. When you beat that opponent, therefore getting 1 star, the next opponent is unlocked. However, to unlock the Bonuses Match linked to that opponent, you must have at least 2 stars, which includes the one you get for beating him.There are 2 Tour modes, each containing the same 4 competitions, each divided into 3 Rounds. Each competition is increasingly more difficult. In order of easiest to hardest: Sky Lounge Cup, Exchange Square Cup, West Coast Trophy, and Valley Lodge Masters. Initially you only have access to the Sky Lounge and Exchange Square Cup, but you can unlock them in order, starting from the Exchange Square Cup if you wish.Each Competition features a new area, and each Round features a version of that area at a different time of day. So Round 1 for the Sky Lounge During the Day, Round 2 for Evening, and Round 3 for night. Each time of day alters the look of the area to varying degrees, all of which look great. Beating a round will unlock that location/time to choose when creating a Versus or Online game.Now for the Bonus Matches I mentioned. In each Tour mode, there are various 'Bonus Matches' which deviate from the 8/9 Ball ruleset, which are Straight, Rotation, Killer, 3 Ball, etc. Completing the bonus match will award you a star, and also unlock a new graphic for either your Cue Stick, Table Decal, or Pool Ball skin. Bonus Matches are not necessary for advancing in the Tour.There is also a Versus game mode, which can be against a human player or against the AI. You start with one AI opponent on the easiest difficulty, and you unlock more by defeating them in the 8 and/or 9 Ball Tour. For a Human vs Human Versus game, it's a local multiplayer game, where you either share the keyboard and mouse, or 1 person uses the keyboard/mouse and the other uses a Controller. Theres many ways you can set up a Versus game: You can change the look of the Cue Stick, Pool Balls, and the Table Decal with skins/textures you've unlocked during the Tours Bonus Matches. You can change the ruleset, ranging from the classic 8 Ball and 9 Ball, to Straight Ball, Speed, Killer, Golf, 3 Ball, and Rotation rulesets. Online mode is basically the same, but with added ranked/unranked/custom options.In the main menu there's also "Free Play" mode. This give you the 9 Ball set up, but you can do anything you like. There's no human opponent, and you can consider it a practice mode, especially for practicing your trick shots. You can pick up the cue ball whenever you like and place it wherever you like. Once you pocket all the balls, it simply resets the table. I like to use this mode when I want to relax, practice trick shots, or just goof around and see how many balls I can send flying off the table in one shot. Pity you can't send it through a window. :pAlso in the main menu is Endurance mode. In this mode you need to make shots(also called 'potting' or 'pot') as fast as you can. New balls will constantly spawn, and when the active ball count on the table reaches 24, you lose, so you need to keep potting. After potting enough shots, you'll earn a brief period will the spawn rate will completely stop, giving you some breathing room.One thing that should definitely be mentioned, is the Aim System. There's various aim modes which will project not only where the Cue Ball will go, but the direction of the ball you're hitting. This is great for making not only regular shots, but making trick shots easy too. There's multiple levels of Aim projection, which will gradually decrease how far it will project the shot, then only show the cue ball's path, and finally no aim mode, where it won't even show the Cue Ball's path. This, combined Free Play, will help you become better and better.While we're on the subject of practicing, there's a Tutorial mode in the Single Player menu. This will teach you how to do various shots. From simple straight shots, to Jumping, Curving, Knife, Kick, Bank, etc shots. It's great for learning the various moves. There is an odd graphic bug/oversight. While the tutorial plays, it will always show the keyboard/mouse bindings at the top, but when it's your turn to try the shot, it'll show whatever control method you're using. It's not a big deal, since the controls are simple and there's even an option in the settings that will let you push the Help button, which is 'X' for controllers and 'K' for Keyboard, and will show all the controls at anytime and any game mode, so this game does great for helping beginners, but has the option of turning them off. You can save replays of your matches too, so you can view them again. Also works in Free Play mode. The replay feature isn't as fleshed out as it could have been, but it's okay.People have complained about controls, so I'll throw in my opinion: After playing it for a few hours with both the Xbox Controller and Keyboard, it does feel like it was intended to be played with the controller. HOWEVER, the keyboard and mouse controls are still great and nowhere near as bad as some have complained, and feel almost completely natural. I say 'almost' because I'm the type to keep my hand in a single position and dislike moving it too far. However, it's very easy to remap the keys closer, and honestly, only 2 or 3 keys I needed to move closer, and they weren't even necessary really. And in the Straight ruleset, the shot calling function was very awkward and overly sensitive for the keyboard/mouse. The replay modes keyboard/mouse controls are also awkward to use no matter how you map it.Anyway, to summarize: Great pool game, many game modes, online multiplayer, and great controls for BOTH the keyboard+mouse and controller. Most of the complaints on the keyboard controls are over exaggerated.Master Edit: Apparently there's a character limit to reviews, though I'm guessing it's rare for someone to waffle on enough to reach it. So yeah, I've edited this review over 6 times adding more info and correcting mistakes. Had to delete the other edits to make room for more waffle.

content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
												Recommended.Depending on what you're looking for the single player campaigns are lacking.  There are a lot of opponents but they felt very identical to play against.  However, I wasn't working towards the challenges against each opponent and going for those could be fun, although they're usually pretty same-y (x match score, x-ball streak).  Additionally, there are actual stand-alone challenges but of the few I played they were pretty boring.  While they did break up gameplay when I found it necessary, the AI is so unpredictable  that modes like speed challenge or 3 ball just aren't that much fun.As a 8-Ball and 9-ball simulator, though, this game is pretty excellent.  The physics work, there's a guiding shot marker to help  you learn how to shoot better (this can also be turned off, or reduced) and the game is pretty.  Pool Nations ia  large step up from those crappy flash games.Online play seems functional.  At the very least I didn't have any issues with it.  For online play there are a lot of interesting game modes past 8 and 9 ball including 3 ball, straight, rotation, speed, and killer.  Of those I only tried killer (possibly speed in the campaign) and it was fun, though it felt more like a quick distraction between a few rounds of 8 ball.So yes, I recommend this game.  It's much, much better for me than driving down to the Pool Hall, especially when I can't guarantee I'll have anyone to play.  This is something I needed in my life and it's nice to have, but I also recognize that it's probably not for everyone.  I've only played a handful of times and only for a few hours total.  It's definitely a pick up and play for a few rounds and then put it down for a few weeks kind of game, though that is exactly what I wanted.Oh, and I guess there are features that haven't been implemented yet but are on their way like the box of tricks.  That mode seems fairly interesting.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
												Being a gentlemanly fan of both snooker and pool myself, I felt I should give this game a go, and I was most certainly not dissapointed! It is most certainly a woppingly spiffing game, and I must say, it does rather feel as if you are really playing this fine game in real life! You are able to do tournaments, do some rather excellent trick shots and although the challenges make me want to throw my tea across the room sometimes (which would be a scandal!) it only makes you want to play it more and take those challenges head on. By golly! I give this riveting game 4 Cups of Tea out of 5! Tally-Ho!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 22, 2014
												Extremely fun game!Pool Nation has a very realistic physics engine, with very nice graphics. There is a ton of achievements to be unlocked and replayability is great.There are, however, a few problems with this game: a) If you simply want a quick game, it isn't so quick, because there are lots of menus to go through, and the cutscenes before the game starts are painfully long. b) the graphics are great, beautiful, but some of them very unrealistic when it comes to pool tables. The developers did a great job exploring the rendering engine they had in hand, but I believe there was no need for so many fancy and colored pool tables and balls. IMHO, a pool table has to be green. Forget about everything else, because it just gets in the way of the game.Neverthless, Pool Nation is a great game, worth every penny. I am not afraid to say it is possibly the best pool game ever made, and the closest thing to a pool/billiard/snooker simulator.If the developers ever read this, I have a suggestion: make it possible to create custom game rules, like we do in real life.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2013
												This game is just brilliant. If you're looking for a highly realistic pool simulator, look elsewhere. If you're looking for a reasonably realistic pool sim with awesome trick shot potential, you've found it and believe me, jumping the cue ball in slow motion, over your opponents blockade and potting your own ball in the process is completely badass.I love it.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												First off, this is the best looking pool game I have ever played.  Period.Beautiful pool tables, balls, and environments that are fully fleshed out and animated to give you a real sense of immersion.The game is full of details that kept surprising me.  Some of them are so subtle that you can't even notice it unless you are watching the replay.  Here are a few things you will find:* 3rd dimension: this isn't a simple pool game where balls stick to the table.  All pool balls can be knocked off, up in the air, and over other balls (given enough force).* When hit certain ways, chalk will fall off stick and sprinkle on the table.* Tiny woven texture on table material when you zoom in close* Sides of table (bumpers) actually give and bend in when a ball hits them with force (very hard to notice without replay!)For single player there is enough to keep you busy for awhile with tournaments in various game types against different AI.  One thing I found keeping my interest is bonuses you can try for on each game in a tournament.  For instance one might have a bonus for pulling off a jump shot during the match.  You can still win the game, but there will be a bonus for doing the jump shot.  Earning these stars while winning makes for a fun challenge.There are also many ball styles, cue sticks, and locations to unlock through single player.  So far every ball set I have unlocked has been great looking and is a good incentive to keep playing and unlock more.For multiplayer, it is fully functional in both same computer and online play.  Unsurprisingly you have to wait awhile for a game to show up, but that's less the fault of the game and more of the popularity of online pool :).Last I should go over the physics.  This is a tough point to argue because so many factors go into pool physics and without a doubt there is no game out there that is 100% accurate.  If you have ever seen a ball hit another ball at high speed in close up slow motion you'll see what I mean.  Not to mention there are many different ball sizes/weight, table materials and cue sticks used in different areas that add to the difficulty in comparing this to the real world.All I can say for sure is the physics seem real and have been really fun.  Added to the ability to hit the ball just where I want at power levels I never could in RL the game makes you feel like a pool master.Game is on sale for $1.99 currently.  Sell a couple summer trading cards and pick it up!

content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												This is an awesome pool simulator. I think it is even the only pool table game on Steam! That is great because I love pool table. The graphics are fantastic, and the style is very modern. You are usually playing in a tall apartment building. The AI's are very smart, I wish they could use the AI's as a feature. They could make two AI's play against each other, creating a randomly generated game of pool table. I think it would be fun to watch! Anyways, I read some reviews about the .exe crashing, and unfortunately, as good as this game is, the glitch is true. The game does crash, almost every play through. I got one in my first minute opening the game. Then I tried again, and then it happened after 30 minutes of playing. It is really hard to sit down and enjoy the game when it randomly crashes. You never know when either, sometimes it's during the splash screen, and sometimes during gameplay. It is hard to sit down, relax, and enjoy the game, when it crashes spontaneously. The developers have a gem, and they are letting a stupid glitch put it to waste. Please fix the game. And also do the AI thing! I'd love to see 2 AI's play against each other. It would create a randomly generated game of pool table.

												Excellent Pool simulation with superb physics and awesome visuals. The game plays well but the locations lack a little variety. Its certainly worth the purchase and will provide hours of fun and is certainly the best pool game to hit the PC in a long time.There is a choice of 8 ball and 9 ball play plus various other novel play modes inc speed pool, golf and killer mode.The control of the game is intuitive and the developers continue to improve the game.To sum things up I think there was a gap in the market for a good pool game on the PC and this one fills it nicely!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												Nice little Billiardsim, at least the only available on steam wich is worth to be played. Full HD, good physics, nice gfx & sfx, local and also online mp wich is easy to access and uses steam functions like invite friend from friendlist. The difficulty in the standart setting for a experienced pool player is way to easy - you will feel like a billiardproof when having all the helping lines turn on. IF you turn off the helping lines or just set them to one of the 4 other presets like champion the game will become more like the real feeling because not every shot will be a putting. Different type of Billiard games makes it interesting to play again. And there is also a snooker mode announced wich i look forward too. Play this with a friend online or local is the most fun, but also the single player option serve some fun. For experienced and for newcomers this game is worth every penny. You can even train your real skills this way without killing some poolshops tables ^^. As some kind of bonus you can customize your tables , cues and also all the billiard balls.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Great pool game from the graphics to the ball physics. Controls feel great, especially using the mouse as a virtual cue system. Graphics are crisp and colourful with great reflections on balls. Sound is good, music isn't too annoying buy can be turned off if you prefer (which I do). Its challaneging with every game in its tournaments having 3 stars you can unlock for doing specific things like skill shots or winning without losing a frame etc. This means even if you win the tournaments you can go back to specific matches in the tournaments to try and unlock the stars. Lots of unlockable cues, ball sets, locations and decals for the tables.My only downside would be that I hoped more people would be playing this game online. I have found and played people online but there doesn't appear to be many. Hopefully this side of things will improve but even without online gameplay the game is great and well worth the asking price. Best pool game on the PC by far.

I recommend you use a controller if you're able to.I'm not sure if I would recommend this as a $10 game though, since I picked it up heavily discounted in one of the seasonal sales. If you're interested in getting it then wait for a sale -- it'll probably be like $1 or $2.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												This game really caught my eye on steam, and how could it not, it’s so very very shiny. Released originally on PSN Cherry Pop ported their billiards game over to the PC and is available for $10 via steam.What we have here is really a modern pool game. A sparkling beautiful graphics engine combined with an impressive realistic physics engine all to send shiny balls flying around a table. It’s smooth, it’s pretty, it’s gorgeous. (click on some of my high-res screenshots and see for yourself!) Really what else do you need to know? If you like pool games then it’s for you, if you don’t, all the shiny graphics in the world probably won’t change your mind. What you might expect from a pool game is all here, an 8-ball and 9-ball tour to play through with slowly increasing difficulty as well as some other game modes to throw in some variety.There are also arbitrary points systems that award you points based upon added difficulty of shots (kinda like the way skater games give you points for harder tricks) and as you progress through each tour there are challenges to meet in each match to unlock extra goodies. It’s all your typical completionist fluff we’ve grown to expect from games these days but they do add some extra challenge and drives you to try to be more creative as you play. I also found I enjoyed most of the challenge modes that are unlocked during the tour play although a couple get a little tedious and boring.Everything in the game is well crafted, the table is high textured, the balls well polished and reflective, and even the backgrounds are rich with detail and eye candy. The art style is beautiful and there’s even interesting little blurbs written about each opponent you play against. But all of this eye candy is just background noise to distract you from pocketing those balls! The game really shines though when it comes to trick-shots. Jump shots, draw backs, kick shots, even riding the rail is all possible with the engine. With full control to put on as much english and angle on your shot as you’d like you can put together some pretty sweet shots. Thanks to the shot guides they are not very difficult to learn and once you start pulling them off with regularity your options with each shot open wide. Best of all, the AI knows and uses them just as well which creates quite a challenge as you progress through the game.The trick-shots are definitely best seen in video as screenshots cannot do them proper justice. You’ll be hopping over balls and making crazy draw backs in no time making you feel quite the awesome player. The game is, however, not without it’s flaws. A common complaint I have of many games, the music started to get annoying to me but this is not the first game I’ve had to mute the music and play my own. It is also clear that it is a port rather than designed specifically for the PC.The menus sometimes feel a bit awkward navigating with a mouse and I feel some of the controls are awkward. For example rotating my cue around the cue ball to line up a shot only involves moving mouse left or right, yet my natural inclination is to try to circle the mouse around the cue ball. It made for some very frustrating moments until I realized this. Also I found the video replay system to be- clunky at best. Still even with these small complaints I’d definitely recommend the game if you ever find yourself wanting to shoot some pool.Nailed it!Nailed it!Final Score:Graphics: 10/10Game Play: 8/10Music / Ambiance: 8/10Story: -/10Value: 8/10Overall: 8.5/10Read more indy game reviews on my blog!http://markofithian.com

												Very nice pool game, even fun to play alone vs AISingleplayer has: Tutorial, box of trickshots (or something) 4x 9-ball tours, 4x 8-ball toursTours include certain ammount of AI matches.Each match can give you 1-3 stars.Usually you get 1 star by winning match which also unlocks next match and then other stars you get when doing certain task during the match (you still need to win the match also)Tasks like: Perform comboshot during match or kickshot or get streak of 7 balls in match + much of other stuff like that.Also getting 2 stars in certain matches will unlock bonus match in that tour.Each tour contain few bonus match to unlock.I have completed first 9-ball tour by 71% and it took me 6 hours, so if other tours take as much time it means total 48h of gameplay and still you havent compeleted everything by 100%, so this game has plenty of nice singleplayer content for your money.Totally recommend this game but be warned: Multiplayer is dead, so dont buy it for online multiplayer

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												There really is no negative reviews this game should get.  People buying it know exactly what the game is: billiards.  It's not like there is at all any surprise.  You don't get surprised that Taco Bell serves tacos so why would you be surprised a game called Pool Nation is anything but pool? Overall I found it to be addictive fun.  When I bought it, the game was at I'd say a dollar and it was the best thing I've ever bought with only one dollar (NOT EVEN TAX!) I could have bought gum or soda with that $1 but that won't last me and is not as enjoyable as something you can share in an online session with.  If you like or would want to learn about playing pool, this game is honestly the best (and only) pool game I know of.  The only con is that because it is for the computer, the gameplay takes some time to get used to (whether you use the keyboard or a controller).  However, the amount of time it takes you to learn how to play with buttons (versus using an actual pool stick) is time that you also gain experience and tips; so realistically you are not losing anything but gaining more than you pay for!  Being taught how to play a sport (that can be used for real life) is so worth paying only a dollar for.  McDonald's doesn't even have a dollar menu anymore; it's like $1.50.  Though I was fortunate at the time and the game is back to its' original price, the pirce is $9.99 (NOT EVEN $10!!) so it's not too bad a price.  I SAY GET IT!!! But who am I to say?  See for yourself.  You won't be displeased.+Physics: Way too realistic! :)+Price: Cheap!!! :)+Customizable: To some degree.+ Music: Relaxing (If you are immature like me, I thought of porno background music).

Posted: January 4, 2014
												Very well done Pool game. I'm a long time Virtual Pool player (15+ years). Physics could be a teeny bit better, like the english (ball spin) physics. In real life, pockets on a pool table have angled cushions around the pocket to help your ball in, should you hit them correctly...In this game however, if you don't hit the ball straight into the pocket, it's not going in. If you hit the angled portion around the pocket, it will just reject your ball much of the time, really unforgiving but challenging. Hard to explain...think of a basketball hoop where if you didn't swish the ball, the ball would never go in. I don't use that aim assist or flashback bullcrap either. That's for sissies!Easy on the eyes and shiny as hell, though. I think the lighting on the balls (ha, balls) could be a lot better. Also, like the virtual pool series, it's a great game to play and mute all the in-game sound if you're in the mood to rock out to some of your mp3s, you can fully enjoy your music and the game at the same time.The game is still in development so I think it will improve over time. There are few odd glitches here and there. Buy this game the next time it's on sale and come play with me!

Posted: June 2, 2014
												Pool Nation is how I imagine my life would be if I was a lottery winner, a pimp, or Jordan Belfort. The game deserves a solid 9/10, losing out on full marks quite simply because the only thing it’s missing is pornstars wandering around in 6inch stilettos and lines of coke and rolled up 20 dollar bills laying haphazardly about the place.  What this game does extremely well, is that it makes you feel important. It draws you into a world where you can be the person you’ve always wanted to be in real life, a world where paying $15 for a drink wouldn’t make you penniless by end of the evening, a world where every woman wants to blow you and every dude……. Well who gives a f*#k if every chick wants to blow you right?? Pool Nation offers something different than any other pool game I’ve seen before. You can’t quite tell what it is but it’s shinier, sexier, it’s got more curves and it leaves you wanting more every time. In the words of Jon Martello, this is a game where ‘I just ♥♥♥♥in’ lose myself’.

Posted: April 24, 2014
Good Pool Game, Good Product=========This is a very polished game. Great graphics, several game types, tutorials to teach you basic shots through trick shots which you can go back to between games. Good controls for both keyboard/mouse and controller: placement cue on ball(for spins), angle of cue(for jumps), power lock-in and short path prediction. Good physics simulation that has felt natural on every shot.  You can do free-play, tournaments, two-player local or online play, with plenty of customizations.  Music is well done and catchy, too.I am very surprised by the level of polish, the attention to detail, menu controls, load times, re-load times, game options et cetera.  This is a pretty good pool game, but also a fine product in general. The developers did a good job all around.I haven't played long enough to speak to the AI which is a fairly big deal for a game like this, but I have been impressed with everything else so far. There are about 42 different "characters" with various degrees of difficulty(novice, veteran, pro). And of course you can play against other people with aim-assist on or off.

Posted: January 14, 2014
												It's a pool game. That should be enough to get you to buy it. However, this game is fantastic. You can see the venue in the reflection on the balls. The controls are great and allow you to do swerve shots, jump shots, and knife-edges by setting power, cue angle, and spin. There are a lot of different matches in multiple single player modes (9-ball, 8-ball, etc.) and there are challenges in each one. Some matches unlock a bonus stage in which you can unlock new ball designs or new cues by beating your opponent in things like 3 ball, straight pool, and killer. The only thing it's missing is player models, but that doesn't take away from the game at all. Seriously, it's worth the 10 bucks, but if it's ever on sale, you really should buy it!

												Looks gorgeous, lots of characters to play against and great challenges.  It's one of those games that makes you feel good about how good you've got. Posted: August 2, 2014
												I think Pool Nation is one of those games that knows exactly what it is, and doesn't try to be anything it's not. Pool Nation is a billiards game, that's it. It's a slick-looking multiplayer/singleplayer campain billiards game.And it's fun as hell.Weirdly enough, I'm comparing this to Sniper Elite V2. While the two games' topics are in no way similar, both play out in coincidentaly similar ways. For example, both Pool Nation and Sniper Elite V2 hav slick, shiny graphics that look AMAZING. The graphics on both games look professionally made and I just love it. Graphics haven't been a huge thing for me, but wow, Pool Nation's graphics are actually better that Call of Duty Ghosts, and to top it off, my computer can run it.Another weird similarity is the "killcams". In Sniper Elite V2, if you hit the enemy in a certain place, the camera pans out to the bullet or the enemy, and you get to watch the enemy get shot up close. In Pool Nation, if you make a Skill Shot or just a nice looking shot, the camera sets up on the hole, and you watch the ball fly in. The only difference is, Pool Nation does this less. For me, almost every shot in Sniper Elite was a killcam, and it got annoying as hell (except the ball shots). But the killcams only happen periodically in Pool Nation, and THANK YOU SO MUCH for doing so.And the last thing, if you think about it just a tad, playing pool is almost like sniping. You have to aim carefully at a specifis target (and in some cases many targets) and shoot. Posted: May 6, 2014
												Anyone who likes Pool will like this. The single player and all its unlocks are fairly entertaining but the real joy is found in playing with friends. Unless you turn off the aim assist then you will soon find that you can breeze through the AI players without too much difficulty but, even with it on, it's not so easy to make all the unlocks as it is to win matches. This game is often found on sale (I picked it up from HumbleBundle for around £1.50) and represents astounding value for money. The graphics are clean and sharp and the ball physics are adequately realistic with the exception of some inexplicable ball-off-the-table incidents if you use too much power. 98% - There is simply no better computer simulation of Pool.

Posted: August 2, 2014
												Hands down the best pool game I've played. Graphically, it borders on being a tech demo for high end lighting and reflection effects. It's ridiculously shiny. The felt looks like felt. (I would not be surprised to see this game come bundled with every graphics card released in the next five years. It makes your GPU look like a hero.) The physics are just as good: crisp and consistent. Lots of game modes. Lots of cue sticks, balls, table decals, and pool halls to unlock. (I've played for 9 hours, I'm reasonably good at pool, and I've only opened up the easiest fourth of the unlockables.) Thanks to the quirky descriptions of your opponents before the matches, the game ends up having a ton of personality, considering it doesn't render the players at all, only their ghostly, floating sticks. It's got solid multiplayer, at least for two people. By people I mean friends. You can play big tournaments, in theory, with larger groups of strangers.Perhaps most importantly in the context of 2014 gaming, Pool Nation is getting continued love and support from its devs. Snooker and "Box of Tricks" are both coming soon as free updates, and the devs are active in the forums.As I write this, the game is on sale for $1.50. It's correctly priced at $10, so $1.50 is a steal.

Posted: August 4, 2014
												Good Stuff: Pool Nation is pretty. Well, okay, you can quite plainly see that, but it's fairly pretty gameplay wise, too. Once you get the hang of the controls... Which is easy enough, because the tutorials are quite helpful, and the aiming sight, even on default settings, is actually useful for everything except hardcore kick shots... The game gives you that little bit of extra motivation to up your game by asking you to do challenges while you beat the AI's♥♥♥♥♥ ...Okay, the AI is also quite fair in this game, and so sometimes (especially on 3-ball, an event you'll love to hate) it'll kick your♥♥♥♥♥ Beat a certain number of challenges, you'll get bonus levels. Beat bonus levels, or certain characters, and you'll get customisation for your table decals, cue decals, and ball style.Problems: There *is* online multiplayer for this game, but sadly, it's very, very dead, presumably because pool afficianados prefer a local fix (I sure do!) Also... The high reflection on the balls can sometimes make it difficult to tell what's what, even in Overhead view. Finally, the soundtrack, while chill, gets a little repetitive at times, and doesn't really cover that "Playin' Pool/Billiards in a pub/club" feel.Conclusion: Even for the non-sale price, this game is worth the cash (5 hours in, and while I could *theoretically* beat the AI players in that time, 100%ing each players' challenges is a slightly different story), and for something to relax to, then wonder "Wait a minute, wasn't it 6PM a minute ago?", there's few better things than a game of 'puter Pool.

Posted: August 2, 2014
												I think Pool Nation is one of those games that knows exactly what it is, and doesn't try to be anything it's not. Pool Nation is a billiards game, that's it. It's a slick-looking multiplayer/singleplayer campain billiards game.And it's fun as hell.Weirdly enough, I'm comparing this to Sniper Elite V2. While the two games' topics are in no way similar, both play out in coincidentaly similar ways. For example, both Pool Nation and Sniper Elite V2 hav slick, shiny graphics that look AMAZING. The graphics on both games look professionally made and I just love it. Graphics haven't been a huge thing for me, but wow, Pool Nation's graphics are actually better that Call of Duty Ghosts, and to top it off, my computer can run it.Another weird similarity is the "killcams". In Sniper Elite V2, if you hit the enemy in a certain place, the camera pans out to the bullet or the enemy, and you get to watch the enemy get shot up close. In Pool Nation, if you make a Skill Shot or just a nice looking shot, the camera sets up on the hole, and you watch the ball fly in. The only difference is, Pool Nation does this less. For me, almost every shot in Sniper Elite was a killcam, and it got annoying as hell (except the ball shots). But the killcams only happen periodically in Pool Nation, and THANK YOU SO MUCH for doing so.And the last thing, if you think about it just a tad, playing pool is almost like sniping. You have to aim carefully at a specifis target (and in some cases many targets) and shoot. Not only to you target all if the solid or striped balls in pool, but you also aim at a certain hole and shoot! How weird is that?So now you know why I compared Pool Nation and Sniper Elite V2. Pretty good comparision if you ask me, but overall I think Pool Nation is worth your money. It's an amazing pool game, but its not Steam's only pool game.Buy it and hit me up.

Posted: July 24, 2014
												Looks gorgeous, lots of characters to play against and great challenges.  It's one of those games that makes you feel good about how good you've got.  Personally, I find lots of beer helps too.  Back in the 00's (yes, I'm that old), I used to love Virtual Pool 3 (which I can't get to run on any platform now), and, after a drought of many years, this has filled the void.  I'd change a couple of things, mainly that you could lock your X-axis when your shooting (but this is mitigated by the "fine-tune" key) and I change the power meter thing to a mouse-mapped power (a-la VP3) but apart from that, it's a great pool game.  I'd have to put a shout out for the artwork two, the stylised characters and their back stories is awesome (and it does it all without slam zooms and star wipes)e.  If you've got a hint of imagination, you don't feel like you're playing against some artifically levelled AI (even though you are).  Well done Cherry Pop (now fix the X-axis lock *claps hands* make it so!)Oh, one other thing, the menu system is horrible, could really do with an overhaul.  Thank God you don't have to use it that much!

Posted: January 14, 2014
												It's a pool game. That should be enough to get you to buy it. However, this game is fantastic. You can see the venue in the reflection on the balls. The controls are great and allow you to do swerve shots, jump shots, and knife-edges by setting power, cue angle, and spin. There are a lot of different matches in multiple single player modes (9-ball, 8-ball, etc.) and there are challenges in each one. Some matches unlock a bonus stage in which you can unlock new ball designs or new cues by beating your opponent in things like 3 ball, straight pool, and killer. The only thing it's missing is player models, but that doesn't take away from the game at all. Seriously, it's worth the 10 bucks, but if it's ever on sale, you really should buy it!

Posted: April 24, 2014
Good Pool Game, Good Product=========This is a very polished game. Great graphics, several game types, tutorials to teach you basic shots through trick shots which you can go back to between games. Good controls for both keyboard/mouse and controller: placement cue on ball(for spins), angle of cue(for jumps), power lock-in and short path prediction. Good physics simulation that has felt natural on every shot.  You can do free-play, tournaments, two-player local or online play, with plenty of customizations.  Music is well done and catchy, too.I am very surprised by the level of polish, the attention to detail, menu controls, load times, re-load times, game options et cetera.  This is a pretty good pool game, but also a fine product in general. The developers did a good job all around.I haven't played long enough to speak to the AI which is a fairly big deal for a game like this, but I have been impressed with everything else so far. There are about 42 different "characters" with various degrees of difficulty(novice, veteran, pro). And of course you can play against other people with aim-assist on or off.

Posted: September 21, 2015
												Do you like playing Pool, but can't afford a real Pool table or can't find the space to fit one in your house? If so, then Pool Nation is a game you might enjoy.Modes include free play (which lets you do whatever you want, recognizing no rules whatsoever), Eight Ball, and Nine Ball. The latter two are done in tournaments, where you face progressively more difficult opponents. Each opponent has bonus criteria, which when met, net you more points but also some opponents have extra modes. These extra modes include bonus games (with varying rules) to earn new Pool cues, felt table skins, and ball designs. None of these really matter as far as the game itself is concerned, but it's nice to get something extra when you do better than average. Sound and music are basic, although the music I found a little annoying. Take that with a grain of salt, as I often find music in games to be irritating. The sounds fit the game nicely, although they were nohing to write home about.Graphics are amazing. I grew up in a house with a real Pool table and except for a few angles here and there, the table and balls all look incredibly realistic. You can also view the game from your character's POV or use a top-down view. I'd strongly recommend the latter.The controls include mouse and keyboard or a controller. I used a wired Xbox 360 controller, as I found the analogue sticks to work better than relying on the digital input of the mouse or keyboard. Every once in a while it seemed like the game interpreted my stick movement as much weaker than I intended, but for the most part, it worked very well.One thing that makes this game much, much easier than real Pool is the inclusion of guides. These guides show you where the ball will go when you hit it and adjust on the fly when you change anything about your shot. Some people might see this as cheating, so on higher difficutly levels the guides are reduced or removed entirely. Multiplayer is available, although I have no idea how well it works. I've stuck entirely to single player against the AI. Considering the overall age of Pool Nation as well, there may not be many players left actively searching for games either.I will warn potential buyers that Pool Nation's developer seems to have abandoned the game. If I'm wrong about that, I apologize. To be fair, Pool Nation is 100% done, so there really isn't much more to do other than fix a bug or two if/when they pop up. Pool Nation is on sale a lot on Steam and through third-party stores, like Humble Bundle or Bundle Stars. so I'd suggest waiting for a sale to purchase it. That wait shouldn't be too long.All in all, I'd recommend this game. It's entertaining, relaxing (for the most part), and doesn't require in-depth knowlege of sports or quick reaction times.

Posted: February 28, 2014
												Great game if you love pool / snooker / billiards (those 2 game types will hopefully come soon). The polish is top notch, visuals crisp and stylish, controls nice (pad native too), camera views solid (has top down too), solid AI, unlocks / challenges, save / view replays, trick shots (all the standard spins / tricks and some), current ball and next ball are shown and easy to identify and nice visual aids (and options to increase / decrease this as you please).Aside from the omission of a Snooker game type the only thing missing that would add to the visuals and atmosphere (no doubt the option to turn this off would be needed for lower end systems) is the lack of character models for you and your AI opponents as well as the lack of a crowd in the wonderfully lit / modelled playing environments especially considering the concept character art which gives a good idea of how great this addition would be.Great stuff!

Posted: January 14, 2014
												It's a pool game. That should be enough to get you to buy it. However, this game is fantastic. You can see the venue in the reflection on the balls. The controls are great and allow you to do swerve shots, jump shots, and knife-edges by setting power, cue angle, and spin. There are a lot of different matches in multiple single player modes (9-ball, 8-ball, etc.) and there are challenges in each one. Some matches unlock a bonus stage in which you can unlock new ball designs or new cues by beating your opponent in things like 3 ball, straight pool, and killer. The only thing it's missing is player models, but that doesn't take away from the game at all. Seriously, it's worth the 10 bucks, but if it's ever on sale, you really should buy it!

Posted: July 24, 2014
												Looks gorgeous, lots of characters to play against and great challenges.  It's one of those games that makes you feel good about how good you've got.  Personally, I find lots of beer helps too.  Back in the 00's (yes, I'm that old), I used to love Virtual Pool 3 (which I can't get to run on any platform now), and, after a drought of many years, this has filled the void.  I'd change a couple of things, mainly that you could lock your X-axis when your shooting (but this is mitigated by the "fine-tune" key) and I change the power meter thing to a mouse-mapped power (a-la VP3) but apart from that, it's a great pool game.  I'd have to put a shout out for the artwork two, the stylised characters and their back stories is awesome (and it does it all without slam zooms and star wipes)e.  If you've got a hint of imagination, you don't feel like you're playing against some artifically levelled AI (even though you are).  Well done Cherry Pop (now fix the X-axis lock *claps hands* make it so!)Oh, one other thing, the menu system is horrible, could really do with an overhaul.  Thank God you don't have to use it that much!

Posted: October 4, 2014
												For a billiards game, its actually quite good, with tons of customatization options. graphics are really great, many gamemodes to choose from...PROS:-lots of customatization-Many gamemodes, Normal types like 8 or 9 ball, or fun types like Killer, Straight, and Golf.-Graphics, really shiny and realistic-Slo-Mo-Trick shots-The tiny particles of acrylic that fly off the Cue ball in Slo-Mo when you hit it hard.-Native Xbox 360 controller supportCons:-The physics might be exaggerated a little bit, so you can make awesome trick shots, so if you'r looking for a "100% super realistic," Pool game, pass on this one.

												It's nice for what it is: a Pool game. Gameplay is good, physics are good, graphics are good, controller support is good. It doesn't exactly have the atmosphere of a bar, but that shouldn't be a problem if you like to play a game of Pool here and there. Grab it while it's on sale.

Posted: July 30, 2014
												I've been a eight ball player for a good 12 years now, Seen many "attempts" of games trying to make a decent computerized version of the real thing, Normally they are as tedious as an eight on the break (Best sit down because youre not going to play that game) But this game has the phyisics of an actual table, I can take what i've learned from the table, implement it is this game and visa versaFinally a game i can hone my advanced tactics, Even the wacky stuff which would get your thrown out of any respectable establishment.Be a great learning tool for beginners to get your "sight in" without throwing away $2 each time you want to practice. Has decent spin and ball control, Which is highly commendable for a game! AI leaves something to be desired, But the other people seem decent. Great for a warm up, Dust off your cue and go for pub crawl till the early hours of the morning...

Posted: July 4, 2014
												I was apprehensive before getting this game because I've had a few billiards video games over the years and to be frank they all seem to be lacking.  The control of the cue, the physics of the balls, and the plausibility of the shots either make me feel like I'm being guided through the game or is so uncomfortable playing that it's just not enjoyable.  Video billiards has always reminded my of video pinball in that there just isn't a video game that can capture the feel of playing.  While this game "Pool Nation" won't replace the actual feel of playing actual billiards... it's miles ahead of many billiards video game I've played that are out there.  The only comparable game is "Virtual Pool 4", which is a good simulation but "Pool Nation" graphics are a bit better and this game seems a little more reactive to your intent for playing.  In other words, this game "Pool Nation"seems to be a bit more user friendly when trying to do what you want on the table than VP4 is.The game gives you excellent control of the cue that includes spin, english, angle, and power.  The controls are easy to learn but I highly recommend the tutorial in game to learn it.  It's short enough not to get boring and you need to learn the skills to play the game and the tutorial treats each lesson as a segment to complete and check off.  The ball physics are a good feel.  I can see myself lining up the shots and predicting the shots as I would on a regular billiard table.  Nothing's perfect of course but the devs did a good job here in my opinion.There are billiard circuits to play for single player and multiplayer.  There's leaderboards, achievements, and trading cards.  Steam Workshop seems like a natural for this type of game where you should be able to customize locations, cues, tables, rooms, or even players etc.. A good pool game for a nice price... on sale of course.

Posted: June 2, 2014
												Pool Nation is how I imagine my life would be if I was a lottery winner, a pimp, or Jordan Belfort. The game deserves a solid 9/10, losing out on full marks quite simply because the only thing it’s missing is pornstars wandering around in 6inch stilettos and lines of coke and rolled up 20 dollar bills laying haphazardly about the place.  What this game does extremely well, is that it makes you feel important. It draws you into a world where you can be the person you’ve always wanted to be in real life, a world where paying $15 for a drink wouldn’t make you penniless by end of the evening, a world where every woman wants to blow you and every dude……. Well who gives a f*#k if every chick wants to blow you right?? Pool Nation offers something different than any other pool game I’ve seen before. You can’t quite tell what it is but it’s shinier, sexier, it’s got more curves and it leaves you wanting more every time. In the words of Jon Martello, this is a game where ‘I just ♥♥♥♥in’ lose myself’.

Posted: August 2, 2014
												Hands down the best pool game I've played. Graphically, it borders on being a tech demo for high end lighting and reflection effects. It's ridiculously shiny. The felt looks like felt. (I would not be surprised to see this game come bundled with every graphics card released in the next five years. It makes your GPU look like a hero.) The physics are just as good: crisp and consistent. Lots of game modes. Lots of cue sticks, balls, table decals, and pool halls to unlock. (I've played for 9 hours, I'm reasonably good at pool, and I've only opened up the easiest fourth of the unlockables.) Thanks to the quirky descriptions of your opponents before the matches, the game ends up having a ton of personality, considering it doesn't render the players at all, only their ghostly, floating sticks. It's got solid multiplayer, at least for two people. By people I mean friends. You can play big tournaments, in theory, with larger groups of strangers.Perhaps most importantly in the context of 2014 gaming, Pool Nation is getting continued love and support from its devs. Snooker and "Box of Tricks" are both coming soon as free updates, and the devs are active in the forums.As I write this, the game is on sale for $1.50. It's correctly priced at $10, so $1.50 is a steal.

content:
Posted: July 31, 2014
												I can rarely say i've spent 8+ Hours enjoying something i only paid £1.04 for. I'm not usually a player of simulation games, but this game is very enjoyable. Potting is so satisfying and once you start completing skillshots, it's enough to make a grown man make girlish squeals of pleasure. Pros  - Very easy to "pick up & play" the tutorials are well done, but are OPTIONAL, so you can do them whenever you feel like, if at all and repeatable, so you can brush up on certain types of shots if you are having difficulty.  - All of the things that make this more game than simulation can be turned off or not used. Those who want a challenge don't have to have aiming lines or use flashbacks.  - Loads of unlockable customisation options, unlike certain simulators where to get a new table or cues (or trains or pinballs) you have to get your wallet out, 95+% of the customisation options are unlockable by beating different challenges or tours.  - Each match in a tour comes with 2 challenges that require you to win the match in certain ways, such as using a particular shot or getting a high score, etc, giving completionists more to achieve.  - Scrolling the mouse back & forth to control the cue is enjoyable - The graphics are amazing. Bearing in mind i'm playing this on a laptop, it looks beautiful. I would go as far as saying this is the best looking game i've run on this, with no framerate drops. Cons - The menu can occasionally get fiddly.  - Sometimes, when trying to aim the cue with the middle-mouse-button, the camera pans up instead.  - Extremely rare crashes. Had 2 so far, but i'm unsure if that's something to do with my hardware to be honest. Seriously, just look through the rest of the reviews. There are HUNDREDS of reviews, all positive, some are casual players, some are hardcore simulation players, all of them love it. Even when this game isn't on sale, it is totally worth the full asking price. If you're even slightly interested in this game, pick it up, you won't be disappointed.

Posted: April 4, 2014
												To say that Pool Nation is a great billiards game is an understatement. I dare say that it can take someone with little to no interest in pool and turn them in to a fan after just a few minutes of play. The controls feel very natural and with the help of tutorials, you will be pulling off jump, combos, and bank shots like the pros. This game is the yard stick that all other pool games should measure themselves by. The graphics are gorgeous and the music is very Zen. Mix in the clacking of pool balls and you'll find yourself a serene yet challenging experience. I highly recommend for anyone who wants a game you can play for a few minutes or hours on end. My only wish would be for more than two player support. Perhaps to watch an online game in a "odd man out plays winner" scenario.
