Posted: June 25, 2014
												UPDATED TO INCLUDE BOX OF TRICKSMy review will cover the following:1. What is good about the game2. What is not so goodTHE GOODFirst off, the game is absolutely beautiful in every way; beautifully optimized, beautiful physics, beautiful graphics, etc.I've always enjoyed playing pool ever since I was young, whether it be at the arcade, bowling alley, or pool hall, I always enjoyed it; and up until this game, I considered the ONLY GOOD pool video game in existence is Pool Paradise[en.wikipedia.org], which I had owned for the Nintendo Gamecube and still have for pc. Pool Nation is a more modern version of Pool Paradise, doesn't have as many features as Pool Paradise (like Darts, Crazy Tables, Skee Ball, that canon and coconuts game, among things)I feel Pool Nation doesn't really live up to Pool Paradise, but is a good pool game, nonetheless; less than five minutes into my first playthrough of Pool Nation, I was immediately addicted to it.But enough rambling, let's get down to what's good in Pool Nation.Quality:Without a doubt, for an indie game, the quality is amazing. The optimization, which is usually lacking in indie games, is perfect.Physics:The physics engine is awesome, right up there with Pool Paradise. When I'd look at other pool games, other than Pool Paradise, the physics would be a disaster, either too stiff or too loose; Pool Nation's physics are as true to the real game as you can get. With precise cue control, you can curve, give spin, jump, etc, to your heart's content!Textures:The textures are beautiful; from the detailed wood grain of the cues, to the fine threads of the pool table mat, everything's in stunning detail. With realtime ball reflections to stunning environments, Pool Nation is in a league all its own!Music:An awesome soundtrack is there to set the mood and keep you company while you play. From light piano music, to downright funky, it's got you set. With each location having its own custom music pieces, the variety is right up there.Unlocks:As you progress and beat certain challenges, you can unlock new cues, ball sets, and mat decals; a vast array to accompany anyone's tastes and wants!Sound:As a sound designer, this is my bread and butter. Pool Nation's sounds are top notch; everything from the cue hitting the cue ball, the balls hitting each other, hitting the cushions, going into the pockets, and to bouncing off the table and hitting the floor are superb. I was actually surprised when I heard the ball bouncing on the floor after it left the table, nice and lively with reverb!Endurance:Not my most favorite gamemode ever, but it certainly is one that'll keep you on the edge of your seat, your palms will sweat, your heart will race, and will truly test how good and quick you are.Slow mo:The slow mo feature is a nice touch. Your last ball is going for the pocket, you're not sure if it'll make it, the slow mo kicks in showing the pocket, as the ball eases in in stunning, glossy, detail, it slowly reaches the end of the mat, you're on the edge of your seat...BOOM it tips off the edge and goes in, you win! It's also great for those action shots with the ball cruising into the pocket.Replay:The replay is awesome. Just pulled off the most amazing shot ever and want to see it again in slow mo? No problem, the replay feature's got your back! Everything from chalk dust to cushion distension can be seen in replay, and features allow you to slow down and move the camera to get a nice look on all the action that took place! (UPDATE, read below)THE BADIt pains me to say it but, not everything's perfect in this game.BUGS:Occasionally, the music will cut out and all you can hear is the ambience and regular sounds. Sometimes the music will come back, but sometimes it doesn't.Random crashes. The game's full of them. Crashed on startup, crashed multiple times after beating and opponent. I think it's due to the saving. Trying to return to the game after Alt+Tabbing also causes the game to crash sometimes, other times you CAN'T get back in.Chat. When typing in chat, sometimes a key will appear as though it was pressed more than once and sometimes not at all, causing "Sttuf  likkeths.  You knw wha   I mn?"Your cue, balls, and mat decal will sometimes reset to default. It always resets after restarting the game.Certain moves will not register, especially banks and kicks at certain times.EVERYTHING ELSE:The chat can sometimes interfere with a shot.Some hud/menu things can also interfere with gameplay.Spin from the cue ball does not transfer to the object ball. A feature that takes away the realism. It's common physics, "for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction." The cue ball is spinning right, and when it hits the object ball, the object ball should spin left, therefore adding more control; even Pool Paradise had this feature.Bag of Tricks REQUIRES purchasing dlc packs, without said dlc, you get a very small number of "Starter" objects, which don't help you create anything worth while.The replay mechanic has been changed. You can no longer slow replays, it's either start off slow or build up to faster, or, reverse slow or build up. You can't start off normal speed and then do a dramatic slow down. The controls were changed, too and are, in my opinion, pretty condescending.A new dlc has been put in the store that will unlock ALL unlockables (other than dlc unlocks) without the need of having to progress which is, in my opinion, the lazy man's dlc.Other than that, this game is a must have for anybody who loves pool!

												The best pool game i ever played.It has multiple settings of aim-guide, including the option to disable it at all (for hardcore players).With the aim-guide, you'll be surprised how quickly you'll be doing absolutely amazing tricks! The challenge then becomes doing the same stuff with less and less help from the aim-guide. It has a multiplayer mode, but the singleplayer is quite good too, it's challenging and the AI usually don't do stupid things.It gets also very cheap on sales. Unless you hate pool, there's no reason to not get this game.

Posted: March 28
												Being an avid pool player IRL I have downloaded a few billiard games both on PC and Android. I truly can say that this is one of the best poll games I have played. If you have never picked up a pool stick before this game is created to help you learn all you need to know on how to play. In no time, you will be preforming curve and jump shots. This game has everything an avid pool player would look for. I can see myself playing this game for years to come without the need to find a better game. I love 8 ball, 9 ball and straight pool. I am not into the other billiards games like Snooker, Carrom or Crokinole so this game is ideal for me. I like the fact that you have bonus achievements to try and accomplish during each match to obtain a 3-star winning. It’s not just point and shoot over and over. The graphics are sweet eye candy and the music must be from some relaxing waterfall video because it can almost put you to sleep. This game is a must have for my library.  RATE: 9 1/2 OUT OF 10

content:
Posted: April 2, 2014
												As close as possible to get to the real thing.  The ability to take trick shots is well balanced with practical physics, making for an enthralling sim.  ...this game makes me laugh & smile.  If you're new Pool Nation is accomodating, featuring a few different ways to practice & easy to learn (if a bit slippery at first) controls.  A pro can appreciate the tournament structures, the spot on rulesets, the tricks, & the challenges, which are a bit like wagers in a bar.  Quite realistic, that.  Pool Nation is rendered beautifully & has all the charm & atmosphere of Poker Night 2's outlandish settings.  The music is well mixed, adding to the full effect.  Everyone should own this game.  If you can't find some pleasure in this sim, you should probably see a shrink.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
												When I first got this game, I was hoping so much, that it would be pretty much just like Virtual Pool 3, but with better graphics. Essentially, that's pretty much what I got! At first, I wasn't sure if I liked the "feel" of it as much, but once I'd played a good few games, I find I do like it a lot! The only bad things I have to say about it (and it's not even that bad) is that there is a slight difference in the movement of the cue stick between single player, and multiplayer. I'm not sure if it's just my pc or not, but for me, single player feels very 1:1 in terms of how much I expect the cue stick to move in relation to how much (and quickly) I move the mouse. In multiplayer for me, it feels like there is a very very slight delay between me moving the mouse, and it moving the cue. When I say very very slight, I really mean it. It's easily the kind of thing you can get used to, and after playing several games, I barely even notice it myself, unless I actually jump from playing single player, straight in to an online game. The only other disappointing thing, is that it doesn't have Snooker. If it did, this would be the penultimate pool game! Certainly not a deal breaker though! If you like pool games, or are a fan of the Virtual Pool series, you won't regret purchasing this at all. I've played many many games online with a friend of mine (usually several matches a day!) and we both get great enjoyment from doing so! As you can see from my playtime, I've already spent a significant amount of time playing this, and it's only going to grow further! Trick shots are hard to master, but once you get your head around how to do jump shots and curve shots, whole new ways of playing become apparent, and you truly start to feel like a master!The single player is challenging and fun, and having mini goals in each round keeps you coming back for more, since usually completing those goals, leads to unlocking new locations, balls, decals and cues.At it's current price of $1.49, you'd be crazy not to grab a copy! I think I payed $3 or $5 for it at the time of purchase, but I would say that even if it was $10-$15, it's still worth every cent!

content:
Posted: April 26, 2015
												This is the best virtual pool game that I've ever played, period. It's addictive and instructive. My Real Life™ game has improved, thanks to the accurate physics and cue aiming system. As an enthusiastic supporter, who wants this game to become a household name, I have a few humble suggestions for the developers:1.  Please add more tournaments featuring more game types:      a. British 8-ball      b. Snooker      c. Straight      d. anything else you can think of...2.  Maybe add more types of tables... at my local pool hall, there are, at least, three distinct styles of tables:      a. Quarter-drop - small green, big pockets      b. Big/Big - big green, big pockets      c. Big/Little - big green, itty-bitty pockets      d. Is "Bumper Pool" a real thing? I'd play it...3.  I am far more likely to pay for decals, cues, balls, and locations, than I am for trick-shot materials.4.  Some sort of local playlist ability for the background music.I'd like to say again...I'm a HUGE supporter of this game. If you like to shoot pool, in Real Life™, you'll love this game.

												A pretty solid pool game, which is something Steam has being missing for a while. The physics feel right, the game looks pretty and it has several game modes to keep you entertained enough. Endurance mode is an especially neat game which tests the players skills over a prolonged (10-15 minute or so) session. With the Box Of Tricks DLC coming for free in the near future, and a (paid for) Snooker expansion planned as well, you can't really grumble at the game...providing you're into pool, duh!

content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												This is one game that made me hate the Steam special sales. I picked it up during the Summer Sale for 6€, asked a friend if he's interested in playing some pool and he was, bought it too and we enjoy the hell out of it, i would pay even 30€ for this game. I played PC Billard games from the 90's on, all the Virtua Pools and whatever is out there and i play Billard in real-life and this is the best simulation i've seen so far. There are a lot of game modes (3-Ball, 8-Ball, 9-Ball, Rotation, Killer, Golf, Speed, Endurance) and a small career style mode where you unlock locations, queues, ball designs and layouts for the table - so it's even fun in single player but absolutely shines in multiplayer. The graphics are nice an shiny and the music is greatBest thing of all is that the developers actually are active in the forums and listen to the fans and their wishes. I can't wait for the trick shoot stuff and the Snooker mode and whatever else they plan.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2015
												Pool Nation is a fun fantasy pool game but I found frustration outweighed my enjoyment over time due to many small issues. I regularly had an issue where stars in levels would not be awarded after the match when the in-match tracking said I had completed the challange and I had won both the game and match. This lead to completing stars up to four times before the game successfully registered them. Another frustrating but not game breaking issue was that the overhead view became blocked on some levels which left me with only the on table view. This view is enough to play on, but still limited my options. A lot of little things like this detracted from the game for me and lead to me sending it to the done pile earlier than it should have been. I found this game to be worth the money I spent, but still fails to be something I can recommend.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												This game is possibly the best pool game I've ever had the pleasure of playing. The sound design is fantastic, the graphics are shiny but non-intrusive, I haven't seen a single physics error. If you want to simulate a game of pool, this will do it almost to a tee.However. I have three reservations. The power meter gets stuck sometimes if the mouse is accidentally pulled to the edge of the window, even on fullscreen. This can cause some dodgy shots. The Endurance challenge instruction page seems to be bugged and will only let you see the last page of it. To be fair, the gist of the 6 page manual is that you need to pot balls fast, but it's not entirely apparent what parameters there are on this activity. The Straight challenge does not account for trick shots or indirect aiming the same way that the rest of the game is, and this is never explained. As such, and as the name might suggest, you should only shoot straight. No jumping, no swerving, don't even think about a combo.Aside from that, a very robust and well designed pool game.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												Best looking billiards sim i've seen. But quite frankly, there are a basket of errors still clearly visible. The UI is wonky, and this game crashes every other time I play it. Its fun, but slow paced. I just hope that the devs continue to support this game as it has quite the potential to be a lot of fun. The biggest downside, is that it flat out does not use the correct rules. Maybe it's a licensing issue, but it certainly is a pain when your opponent scratches on the 8 ball and does not lose the game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												Pool Nation & Bumper Pack BundleIncludes 6 items: Pool Nation, Pool Nation - Flair Pack, Pool Nation - Pack of Pipes, Pool Nation - Ramp Pack, Pool Nation - Skate Pack, Pool Nation - Sports PackFor S$1.95, it wouldn't be a big loss even it sucks. It's a port over from Xbox so there are many problems. It won't be a mainstay but worth playing once in a while, just waiting for multiple ball collision help to come out.PROS1. Good priceEasy entry price and I don't mind supporting Cherry Pop Games at this price level.2. Pool ExplainationsHelped me to understand Pool terms in an easy manner.3. 3D tricksThe old pool games on Yahoo were only 2D and you weren't able to jump balls. In 3D, being able to jump the ball is quite satisfying.CONS1. TutorialsTricks with fine adjustments had a major problem. If you pressed F, the tutorial would give you a green tick even if you we aiming all over the place. 2. GraphicsThe default graphics suck. I couldn't even read the words in the tutorial, I thought Left Click was Left Shift. Tried it on 1280 * 768 resolution @ 60Hz... Much better...3. Overhead viewAs I played the game as a newbie, I realised I would never bother with trick shots. I would just use the Overhead view 4. Multiple ball collisionsThe game can't show how multiple collisions work e.g. proxying a ball. If you hit the cushion to hit your ball, it will only show where the white ball goes to. This turns me off from trying more difficult shots vs winning the game. If the issue is player difficulty, perhaps the developers could create 1. Easy 2. Medium 3. Hard 4. Pro modes for players. With Easy showing how all the balls will move and Pro having zero help.On a side note : Just learned that you need 5 minutes of game time even before you write a review. I changed my review to Yes after playing 8 ball.

												Probably the best, of many pool remakes I have played. It's very humble-feeling, with fantastic, smooth graphics and relaxing music. Not much else to be said. It's got Steam Workshop and plenty of built-in gamemodes, worth a decent amount of play-time. The only notable drawback is the lack of multiplayer matches, but I'm sure the current Summer sale will alleviate that. It's good to have a buddy to play with though, just in case. Another issue is that you can only have 2 player matches, when in reality there are many potential 3 player gamemodes. I play with a friend over Teamspeak, and this is our go-to game when we can't think of anything else to play. Heavily recommend.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												It's kinda tricky to review a Pool game so I will try and break it down into what matters. GraphicsAs you can see in the screenshots the game looks great, it is ported from the Xbox 360 so it will run pretty damn well on almost any computer set up you care to mention and with Anti-alising all the way up it is a very very nice game to look at. The UI is nice and easy to use as well although, whislt the controls have had there names changed. It still asks you to press A, B, Start and Back whenever you want to do something. That is more of a monor niggle thoughGameplayThe Pool on display here is very nice. The balls all act realistically and as far as I can tell things like friction have been modeled very well. In the close up slow-mo shots you get sometimes when a ball is potted you can see that the balls are lifting up and sliding about realistically. The sound design helps to sell this as well, with nice clear sound making it all the more satisfying when the ball drops. MultiplayerAs far as I can tell the multiplayer for this game is dead. Which is a shame and slightly confusing. I couldn't seem to find any games at all in any mode so unless one of your friends has the game it is most likely gonna be solo play for you. OverallConsidering The lack of a decent Pool game on PC and the promise of the release of the Trick Shot mode soon I would say this game is well worth picking up

												I can BARELY recommend this game, and that's only because it does offer some value as a good cool down game after a heavy shooter session. With that being said, I have a huge issue with how the challenge level progresses in this game. The opponents don't get better, you get worse, and that's really irritating. I'm on the final 8 ball tournament level now, and the AI has the same skill level as it was in the beginning. Your controls get worse as the game progresses and there are glitches that will force you to lose the game. So with that being said, if you're looking at this for a serious pool game, I would not suggest. If you're looking for a cool down, time killer, then proceed but be warned.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												Don't buy this billiard-game for actual billiard-games.The focus in this game has been put on "trick-shots": The (extremely 1-1 strict) tutorial even teaches spins & jumps far before the very basics, which in reality would include chaining (or "combos") & bank-shots (bouncing cue or other balls from banks).Don't even bother playing without guidances or other "deflection angle" indicators, especially mainly because the full-power-shot hits like a unrestrained Superman, which will almost 100% guarantee send your cue-ball flying off the table.Also a large number shots that chalk the table simply makes my cringe, especially when the tutorial forces the players to do so at least once (I.E. when pool-stick hits the carpet of the table).So why is still getting an okay from me?Well, like i said, this focus in this game are the indeed the trick-shots, for which the game gives all the needed tools, especially for analyzes and other calculations, which are extremely useful with the recently released optional "playground"-objects.So if you want to try out something even crazier than those seen during artistic-pool-competitions without risk of ruining ones pool-carpet, this is a game for you.Of course, the available amount of game-modes ("8-ball" and so on) do allow playing "normal games" too; just be prepared to do lots of trick-shots instead of "playing normally like in real-life".

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 17, 2014
												The best pool experience on a computer that I know of.9-ball, 8-ball and Straight games are available together with a couple of for-fun modes (speed-potting, lose-a-life-when-you-miss etc.) and endurance (a "survival mode" with extra balls appearing on the table with increasing speed).The game makes it easy to execute the shots you know how to perform in theory (e.g. swerve, jump or back-spin with the 9-ball as a secondary target - and there are tutorials for those), if you just take your time with the available features (such as first-person/top-down view toggle or fine-tuning mode for precise aiming even at table-long distances) and do the necessary adjustments of shot power, spin and butt angle. The balls rebound (from cushions and other balls) in angles depending both on their spin and speed, and the cue ball's trajectory before the first impact (including jumps) can be made visible in different degrees, depending on the novice-to-expert settings.The default control settings turned out to be very practical once being used to, but custom key-binding can be set up. I would like the option of 9-ball games with more than 2 players, but the already available multiplayer options are very nice (whether on a single computer or over network). Whole matches can be archived for replay (I am not sure whether single shots can). Extensive trick-shot options and snooker are supposedly coming in the (near?) future.For any pool-lover that can afford it, I would consider this game a must-have. I got it myself in 90 % discount, but would now take it even for the full price.(Also, the visuals are great and the single-player opponents are funny at times.)

content:
Posted: September 10, 2015
												Very nice pool game, with main limitation being aim assist only calculating trajectories till the first collision. After the first collision, no collisions are taken into account. This means you can't tell how the balls will move if you hit one ball with another (unless you spend 1000s of hours practicing).Game has normal "tournament" mode, where you play against various AI players and collect "stars" for completing challenges, as well as "endurance" mode, where balls are continiously dropped on the field, and an online multiplayer, as well as "versus AI" mode, tricks mode (where you build levels and try to perform some sort of insanity). There could be more, but I mostly play endurance.Graphics is a bit too glossy with all the extra (unneeded, in my personal opinion) reflections and shines. Sound is nice, especially balls hitting other balls. Music is OK, but selection is quite limited, you'll be listening to same tunes over time.Overall, I like the game. It has its flaws, but its quite relaxing.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												I'm not afraid to admit: I bought Pool Nation solely on account of its graphics.Let me elaborate. One of my favorite "sports" games (let's not get into the semantics of whether pool is a sport) of all time has been the original Virtual Pool by Celeris. Since it's been literally years since I played the game, Pool Nation struck all the right chords with me: low price (on sale for $5), great artwork and graphics (ooh, shiny!), and those pangs of nostalgia that I'd been craving.Pool Nation sports a reasonably good tutorial mode and even teaches you how to pull off expert moves like jump shots, knife-edges, and all sorts of careful maneuvers with curving and banking. And those moves will generally score you loads of style points (which, as far as I can tell, are only useful on the in-game leaderboards - there's no way to spend them, and all the unlockables come from milestones in the Tournament modes).If I have only one complaint about Pool Nation, it's that the AI suffers from what I like to refer to as "Worms Syndrome"; in short, the AI will alternate between being a complete and utter stooge (like pocketing the cueball) and being freakishly perfect at their shots (I've seen even low-tier opponents like Cousin Merl pull off insane curving bank shots and manage to pot two or more balls in one hit, on occasion).Of course, this ceases to matter if your intention is playing with friends. This is also a bit of a problem, though, as the online scene for Pool Nation is...well, pretty much nonexistant. You'll pretty much need to talk your friends into buying it if you want to play against anybody other than the AI opponents (or the timer in Endurance Mode). This said, though, given the game's low price, that shouldn't be too hard.And then, yes, there's the graphics. Everything in this game is really shiny. Not "bloom and HDR" shiny, but nice and reflective and smooth. The pool halls you compete in (there are several!) are lovingly rendered and actually remind me of the city from Mirror's Edge. Then there's the character artwork, which is occasionally hilarious (Cousin Merl and Beef Chillingham both elicited chuckles from my usual Livestream audience).So, yes, I give Pool Nation my recommendation. There are no crazy arcade elements (you won't see explosions or fancy particle effects); it's pretty much straight pool with a nice coat of gloss and some solid physics.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2014
												Good game of stripes and solids. Its called 8 ball in the game. I enjoyed this part of the game the best. The computer is good but not overbearing. It brings back a lot of good times playing pool in bars. 9 Ball I want to like but Hate the game play of the computer who seems to be able to make any shot sometimes and then other times will miss the simplest of shots. Its  annoying and makes my want to punch his face. The physics feel very good its not perfect and some of the time it just feels a little off but its very good.I like the unlock system but for whatever reason they made it progressively difficult with 3 stars needed later on to unlock some stuff. However the worst is some of them are busted and dont work like they should. The jump shot is needed to unlock on of the stars and I have done it and not gotten credit for it. Its annoying. A few of the others are just based on luck and thats very annoying as well. The locations you play pool in are very well detailed and looks super great. Sound of the pool is very good. The music can get annoying so I turn it down a lot. Not prefect but very fun and more then worth the $1.50 its on sale for.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												I can BARELY recommend this game, and that's only because it does offer some value as a good cool down game after a heavy shooter session. With that being said, I have a huge issue with how the challenge level progresses in this game. The opponents don't get better, you get worse, and that's really irritating. I'm on the final 8 ball tournament level now, and the AI has the same skill level as it was in the beginning. Your controls get worse as the game progresses and there are glitches that will force you to lose the game. So with that being said, if you're looking at this for a serious pool game, I would not suggest. If you're looking for a cool down, time killer, then proceed but be warned.

6/10 - Decent time waster.A very low-key game to throw on when you aren't in the mood for serious gaming.  It's just something to do.  That does come with some questionable physics, characters whose personalities consist of a one-line synopsis, and campaign modes that drag on with somewhat useless rewards.  It has its time and place and if you can get it for a buck like I did, it's definitely worth that.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												Don't buy this billiard-game for actual billiard-games.The focus in this game has been put on "trick-shots": The (extremely 1-1 strict) tutorial even teaches spins & jumps far before the very basics, which in reality would include chaining (or "combos") & bank-shots (bouncing cue or other balls from banks).Don't even bother playing without guidances or other "deflection angle" indicators, especially mainly because the full-power-shot hits like a unrestrained Superman, which will almost 100% guarantee send your cue-ball flying off the table.Also a large number shots that chalk the table simply makes my cringe, especially when the tutorial forces the players to do so at least once (I.E. when pool-stick hits the carpet of the table).So why is still getting an okay from me?Well, like i said, this focus in this game are the indeed the trick-shots, for which the game gives all the needed tools, especially for analyzes and other calculations, which are extremely useful with the recently released optional "playground"-objects.So if you want to try out something even crazier than those seen during artistic-pool-competitions without risk of ruining ones pool-carpet, this is a game for you.Of course, the available amount of game-modes ("8-ball" and so on) do allow playing "normal games" too; just be prepared to do lots of trick-shots instead of "playing normally like in real-life".

Easy to get used to, easy to play and fun in short doses (tends to get boring after a while just like real pool) Only problem is in single player the AI ramps up from cant sink a shot in the begining but by the second touny the AI pretty much never misses, by the Third YOU CANT MISS A SINGLE SHOT, so the learning curve is more of a cliff, and as for the online matches I think I'm the only person on Steam who owns this game as I have never seen a single multiplayer match or a single person ever online... Customize your balls and cue (but who cares really)... all in all not a bad game if you can get it for cheap (I got it for 2.99), certainaly better than online flash based pool, but not by all that much considering it's still just billards...

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												I play 9-ball and One Pocket a lot, so I was disappointed that there was no One-Pocket tourney option.  Despite that, I am just gushing with praise for this game.  I have never played a PC pool game that GOT IT RIGHT the way this game does.  The feeling of the stroke through the mouse, and the configurations options presented for adjusting that feeling, make this probably the closest one can be to playing the game of pool IRL that I have ever experienced.  Jumping balls off the table, kicking safe, figuring out how much you have to cut the ball with spin, everything.  It feels amazing to sit at a PC and really get the immersion of playing a match.I can't recommend it enough already, but if they ever add a 14:1 or One Pocket gameplay (with an AI that doesn't make me want to shoot myself)  I would absolutely go bananas.   Thank you devs!

content:
Posted: November 21, 2014
												Good looking game with pretty reasonable physics, even if the tables seem to have a lot of drag on them, balls feel like they slide rather than roll. Lining up shots is a chore with iffy mouse controls. This is one of those games where you are controlling something with the mouse (the cue stick), but there is still a mouse pointer in a different area of the screen and they don't correspond at all. It is frustrating and distracting and something I didn't expect to see this side of glitchy Windows XP games. It's like half of the game was designed around a controller and the other half was made for keyboard and mouse.I'm sure there is a bit of a gem buried in here if I dig long enough but it just doesn't seem worth the effort.On the plus side you can totally cheat using a straight edge on your monitor to line up your shots, if you cared enough.Bought on sale for $1.49.12-28-14 edit: Achievements are working again.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2015
												Pool Nation is a game about, well, pool. You hit balls, get them in the pots, battle against AI or online, and rage at your friends for their skill at games. But there are a few flaws in this that make the game's screenshots exagerate how the game actually is.First of all, the physics in the balls are AWFUL. Atleast 20 times (not exageration) during my career I got the ball stuck RIGHT AT THE POT and it didn't go in. If we got it to atleast the edge, give us credit or something. It happens to everybody playing pool, but come on, you didn't have to make it THAT realistic. Besides, who has two extra fingers on each hand?Second, the camera controls are amazingly crap. You MOVE YOUR MOUSE to move the camera. That's nice. How about when I'm trying to hit the ball? Can you KEEP THE CAMERA WHERE IT'S AT????? Half the time I'm trying to fix my camera or looking down the cue or I'm a 500 feet tall man that looks on the very top of the pool table.Last, the AI in this game is the hardest I've ever played. If you don't hit a ball, this AI will hit every striped/coloured ball it sees and you realise that you should use your time wisely because he hit all the balls, he's ready to hit the 8 ball, and you have to hurry and hit all your balls. It took me 3 times to beat the first guy. THE FIRST GUY. I have played pool as well, and I've went through the tutorial.My honest review is that if this game is on sale, don't get your hopes too high but you could buy it. If it's at it's regular $10 price, it's not worth your money.

												Hands down one of my most enjoyed video games purchesed over Steam. In the time that I've beeb playing it I've actially become a better mroe confident player of pool in real life too! Which of ocurse doesnt mean that it transfers over immeditally but aftwer a half a dozen games of pool in real life, I found myself using stuff I learned here to beat my friends quite decidely. If that isn't a good sales pitch for a game I bought to just have fun with on slow nights that I can't play for long perioods of time due to school work, what else will?Oh and it's HUGE! I've played about 3.5 hours thus far and have barely scratche (no pun intended) the surface of what this game offers to those willing to play it! Pretty grateful they made it too, super relazing rarely fustrating but not cheap by any means, this is a serious Pool Table simulater and the computer will make "human choices" but when you do play it and it knows what its doing watch out, for those worried about it though one you learn how to play it well you realize that you could've done just as well if you hadn't tried to push your luck with that last big trick shot. I love it. You might too.

number of helpful: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 21, 2014
												I only disliked one thing about this pool game.  The right joystick on a 360 pad is used to not only select shot power (pulling back the stick), but also to execute a shot (pushing up on the stick).  With all the strategy that goes into each shot, it's too easy to accidentally execute a shot in this manner.  Worse still, it is possible to push up on the stick with no options set, executing a medium power shot with no options set (power, stick angle, ball spin).  In the options, I could see where to remap some things, but not this.  I really want shot execute to be a button, not a stick that I can bump...otherwise, fantastic game, great price!  This flaw is gamebreaking for me though unless I have a solution to it.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2014
												The best (being the only) contemporary pool simulator on Steam, Pool Nation is a reasonable sports simulation marred by controls that vacillate between twitchy and unresponsive, constant hiccups and stuttering, and a borderless windowed mode that locks the mouse to the window. While the core gameplay is functional, it unfortunately is also stuck with a number of UI problems, making it a difficult game to play. 5/10. Buy it on sale, but not at full price.

												Ok, lets make a scenario with this review, im feeling extra nice today. What the bloody ♥♥♥♥ did i buy? I mean, really? I have played some of the cheapest, most broken out of place (impossible) scales of difficulty titles, and this cheap / broken ♥♥♥♥er takes the whole cake. Taking on some CPU in a fighting game can be broken, like shao khan in MK, or seth in SSF4,♥♥♥♥♥♥ill toss asteroth from soul calibur in the mix, all broken, all ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. BUT....BUT....it is a scale. You start with weak foes, and build to the killer fights.(Isnt this a review for a pool game? The hell is this guy going on about?)The point being, i loaded this *cough* game up today, as a friend picked it up for me. I like pool, so sure why not. The very first person you are told to battle is some russian guy with a dog i believe. And after 4 games, (Of which i lost all 4 games) ((2 of those games being a ♥♥♥♥ING clean sweep)) And im greeted with the note, "He used to be the best around, but now he is a joke."No, sir. I AM the joke. Who the ♥♥♥♥ developes day 1 toons to be capable of perfect shots, near to no misses, when the controlls for the humans are rather sketch, and the pressure system for a decent strike is....well messed.I doubt any DEV would ever read this, seeing the game is dated, but this is why research is needed, if only i had known what i was getting, id ask my friend to save his money.Straight up, ♥♥♥♥ this game. As a person who casually plays pool with his friends on the weekly, You would need to play real pool to know why i hate this title so much.

number of helpful: 0 of 7 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
												I love this game for 2 player local co-op.  We use 2 Steam Controllers and play via my Steam Link.This is a fun little pool game that is great for players of all skill levels.  The controls are very intuitive and have been easily picked up by my 75 year old father and others.   We all like the music and find it contributes nicely to the overall relaxing nature of 2 player pool.One of the great features is the versatile aiming aid which shows players the exact path of the cue ball and object ball as they aim and adjust spin and power.  As players get better they can shorten the length of the aid to increase the player skill required to make the shots.  In 2 player local co-op each player may choose the length of the aiming aid independent of the other player.  This means experts can have a very short aiming aid while less-experienced players may have a longer one.  This is a nifty way to handicap games that doesn't make new players feel pandered-to in my experience.A couple of negatives are that the physics are a bit questionable at times, and the aiming aid can permit some absolutely ludicrous shots that would be impossible outside of a physics simulation.  The single player career seems to be nothing more than a way to purposefully gate content... even though you bought the game if you want all the locations and wingdings unlocked you have to buy the "unlock" DLC or slog through the laborious and completely unfun "career".All in all, I recommend this game for local co-op play and pretty much no other reason.  Several times I've checked out the online lobbies and couldn't find anybody to ever play with though YMMV.

												Alright,  I read some reviews before buying this game so I thought this is a good pool game. I'm sorry, it is not. Absolutely not. I've played a lot of pool (and snooker) games in my life, this game is just  not good.Yes, it looks good, if you like unrealistical shiny balls and locations out of a designers wet dream. Where is the bar background? Why don't have the balls scratches? Why is everything so d. shiny, everything looks like through a filter?And then the controls. Neither with gamepad  nor mouse good to play. Inprecise controls plus stiff camera. It doesn't feel like playing  pool at all. Kind of sad. I would give it a 6 out of 10. If the "story mode" is any good later on maybe a 7/10. But the lack of options and configuration possibilities and the big weight on graphics instead of gameplay breaks it for me.

												I Was goign to give a reviw after using the promised Free BOT but it turns out it is tied to paid DLC,they promised that it would be free DLC.Wow was i mislead when the so called free BOT was released and you had to buy DLC to use it fully and to download most the workshop items you need said DLC.They said it took longer they thought and cost more then they thought but you still promised free content and did not deliver.That is part of making games,sometimes you have to eat it and sometimes you make mistakes.You do not get sued then go to cout and say your honor i know i promised to repay and it is in written,but cost of living was more then i planned so i need to take that off the top.That is not how it works you still owe the whole ammount no matter your hardship.As they say never make a promise you can not keep,in short making a promis is risky business and if it does not go as planned. Then be  prepared for it or do not make promises you do no intend to keep no matter what happens.I am for supporting games and buying DLC if it is worth it but not when it is promised for free then later tied to paid stuff or you need the DLC to truly enjoy the game or said DLC is tied to paid DLC.It is a really good pool game with a great community and decent online play and it allows for trick shots and other things and it does look good and has decent single player challanges.There is a ednurance mode where you try and picket as many balls and keep the timer going to see how long you can go.+Looks good plays good nice variety of balls and sticks once unlocked Good Price Easy to learn and fun to play decent Challanges-Could use more contentNeeds custom cues and tables for the workshopNeed DLC to use most of the trick shots in workshopBait and switch promised for DLC gave part DLC and part Pay DLCIn the end before this i would have reccomended said game but due to this bait and switch of sorts i have lost faith in them.I am not sure if i could take in good faith anything else they promise .In  conclusion i must say DO NOT BUY unless  you are ready to pay for DLC and the chance of futher DLC being released like this.Wish they had a mixed button for reviews like if you did not hate the game but did not like it and thought it was maybe worth a buy but it is not for you instead i have to say YES or NO and not a MAYBE.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2014
												Another abysmal port. More abysmal controller support.After having a lot of fun with this on my console, I grabbed it on Steam. Unfortunately like several "controller enabled" titles here, the input progarmming is only half complete. Instead of having a fully functional control mapping feature, it simply picks up input devices and automatically assigns them to functions in the game. This means that if you have other controllers besides a gamepad, like throttles and sliders, menus and views will constantly scroll or move until you find the offending device and unplug or otherwise disable it.This is a fun little game, but I have no desire to constantly unplug or reconfigure controllers just to play, only to have to reconfigure again to play games which use those controllers.On top of this, there was no consideration for alternate resolutions (such as multiple monitor setups). The 3d portion of the game functions, but 2d elements such as splash screens fail to scale properly, making them unreadable.Either make PC games or don't make them. I have no interest in a product that not only doesn't fully support my platform, but forces me to disable features of the platform in order to make the product usable.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												I knew my day was going to improve when the truck pulled up at my home with this game deep within. No ordinary truck, this one was Holy White, and the gold Delivery logo sparkled like a thousand suns reflected through shards of the purest ice formed with unadulterated water collected at the beginning of the universe. The driver, clad in a robe colored the softest of white, floated towards me on the cool fog of a hundred fire extinguishers. He smiled benevolently, like a father looking down upon his only child, and handed me a package wrapped in gold beaten thin to the point where you could see through it. I didn't have to sign, because the driver could see within my heart, and knew that I was pure. Upon opening the package, an angelic choir started to sing, and reached a crescendo as I laid this disc into my system. Instantly, my antiquated equipment transformed into components made from the clearest diamond-semiconductor. The game knew where to install, and hooked itself into the correct directories without help from me - all the while, the choir sang praises to the almighty digital god. With trepidation, I pushed "play," and was instantly enveloped in a sound that echoed the creation of all matter, a sound that vibrated every cell in my body to perfection. I was instantly taken to the next plane, where I saw the all-father. I knew with my entire soul, that all was good in the world.But then I realized the game was blue, so I only gave it one star. I hate blue. 1 */ 5 *

Posted: April 6, 2014
												First off, indy games in my head always equal win; smaller companies generally are able to take greater risks. That having been said, the physics engine in this game is far and away the best that I've seen for a pool game since... ever. Mouse controls are interesting but not impossible at first and after a few playthroughs become incredibly easy. Graphically the game is fairly pretty and I like, for the most part, what they've done.Gameplay is incredible for what it is and, that having been said, the game feels like it should be priced in the mid-20's to early 30's. For the 10 I paid the game feels like a steal. This is as close as you're going to get to a pool game without a stick in your hand. An easy 10/10 for the price.

Posted: June 21, 2014
												Do you remember Rockstar Presents: Table Tennis? Yes, Rockstar, the people that make Grand Theft Auto and Max Payne 3, also made a table tennis (ping-pong to us plebians) game. And it was fantastic. Pool Nation very much riffs off of Rockstar's Table Tennis in the best of ways and presents an amazingly solid product.The models are sparse, as one might expect in a billiards game, but extremely well presented. Textures are rich, colors are vibrant, and the lounges are all fully decked out. The game really does look beautiful. The soundtrack is fairly pedestrian but enjoyable; soft-beat electronic music with a touch of disco.There are no models moving about, so the background does seem rather static. There are no human models at all, period. Floating poolsticks is the order. Your shot takes place behind your stick and the view can be easily manipulated by simply moving the mouse. Symbols will show you where your ball will ricochet, up to a distance, and show your line-of-path. (this can be turned off) Shooting is easily done on the mouse or joystick. It all feels very natural, responsive and the game runs very smoothly thanks to its low required specs.There are unloackbale pool cues, ball sets and decals for the pool tables, but not a lot of visual customization. Workshop integration is in the works which will allow a lot more things to be added to your virtual pool halls.There is a multiplayer for friends and even a searching feature to play with random players. Unfortunately, you can only do 1v1 pool matches. Multiplayer options let you set up frames, aiming helping ability, game type, etc.If you like billiards games, you'll probably enjoy Pool Nation. It's a fast, fun, and easy to pick up game that looks great and is easy to run. I've run this on my Surface Pro 2 with a USB joystick and hooked up to a TV with no problem.

I couldn't say no to that so I bought it.This game is not a game at all. It's a simulator. The tutorial teaches you many basic and advance techniques. It's very well developed and the gameplay can be relaxing. Playing without aiming aid gives one the most reward and this game screams multiplayer fun when played without aiming aid. Unfortunately not too many people play this game online so you will have to play with friends instead most of the time.I wish they will change the power meter from green and blue to anything but both. The tables are green and blue so it's hard to see the power meter when you're playing. I do wish they offer some quaint bar room instead an over modern apartment or a business tower.It's a very good game. I would recommend this game to anyone who has even the slightest interest in pool.

Posted: April 6, 2014
												First off, indy games in my head always equal win; smaller companies generally are able to take greater risks. That having been said, the physics engine in this game is far and away the best that I've seen for a pool game since... ever. Mouse controls are interesting but not impossible at first and after a few playthroughs become incredibly easy. Graphically the game is fairly pretty and I like, for the most part, what they've done.Gameplay is incredible for what it is and, that having been said, the game feels like it should be priced in the mid-20's to early 30's. For the 10 I paid the game feels like a steal. This is as close as you're going to get to a pool game without a stick in your hand. An easy 10/10 for the price.

Posted: April 5, 2014
												From the sound of the clacking of balls, to the feeling you get when you jump-swerve-combo shot your way to victory, this game delivers. The physics are spot-on, the variety of games is ideal, and pretty much everything else serves this game sweetly. The only downside I've found so far is the frontend UI. It feels clunky and ported from a console (perhaps it is). Once you start playing though, the controls are very intuitive and, with a bit of practice, you'll be slinging super trickshots off with ease before you know it.There are a bunch of "special rules" type games to play too, Endurance being the most exhilarating/frustrating. Here, you have to keep potting balls whilst playing to a timer. The longer you take, the more balls are added to the table, eventually maxxing out and ending your game.The camera views are terrific, with full control either 3D or overhead. The graphics are everything you'd want from a pool game, and most important of all, the balls behave as they should.Seriously, this is near-perfect for a pool game. The dodgy front-end aside, this is the best virtual pool experience you'll find on the PC today. Highly recommended.90%

Posted: January 8, 2016
												Aside from the real thing, this is the prettiest game of pool I have ever seen.  The graphics are fantastic, and the physics are phenomenal.It was fun unlocking all of the cosmetic items, and the AI can be pretty challenging at the upper levels (though it becomes a bit obvious when the AI "deliberately" messes up - it will often do things like make 3 tricky shots in a row, then miss the simplest straight-on shot.)If you use the aiming aid, and take time to figure out how to set up skill shots like swerves and jumps, this game will make you feel like a number one pro ace pool shark.  That is the job of this game, and it does it really well.  I will never be that skillful in pool in real life, but this game can give me a taste of what that is like.

Posted: February 8, 2014
												It's got the grahics and the physics that would satisfy any lovers of the pool or snooker game genre. In single player mode I love the tongue in cheek characters you face against in each tournament. The 3 in-match challenges per foe make for a difficult task to those looking at getting every unlock and 100% completion... I like this sort of challenge.Graphically its very smooth with a good use of ambient lighting and color contrast. Theres something of a futuristic style about the in-game themes and pool halls.Another feature I love about this game is the use of trickshots, it can seem alittle exaggerated at times but its always fun to see one played well, or even better playing a beaut yourself. Trick shots without guidelines are where champions leave their mark. As others have said pool nation is a very relaxing experience if you allow it to be, as it's accompanied with a charming soundtrack, sweet visuals and spot on sound effects. It's easy to slump and play...Lastly, the online is where I find the real buzz in pool nation. The community seems friendly so far, though sadly its small in number I believe. (You should join us)For me 5 frames, 8 ball pool, without guide lines is the most enjoyable and of course the most testing in every sense of the word to play online, but its brilliant.9.5/10 - It delivers everything you'd want for this genre

Posted: October 20, 2013
												Really good game. The rendering is top notch, the physics are amazing. It is so satifying to play, especially with some slow mo cameras when you get a good shot, kinda like a sniper bullet. You get points awarded based on the difficulty of the shot too, so it's not just about winning the frame. Loads of content. Really super addictive game modes and just all round fun. I can't recommend this game enough, even if you don't like pool. Easy to pick up and play, lots of customisation such as ball decals, table and new cues. From a technical standpoint, this game is beautiful. A must play. Best pool game out there.

Posted: March 5, 2014
												I've always had a soft spot for pool games, but I've been dissappointed with the offerings available. Nothing's come close to making pool a fun experience on PC since 3D Ultra Cool Pool. Until Now.This game is excellent. How to sum it up... the amount of polish is excellent, graphically stunning, smooth audio tracks and high fidelity, well-placed SFX, but most importantly, the physics engine. It's a trick shot game, where emphasis is placed on being able to perform crazy trick shots in a regular game of 8-ball, 9-ball, or any of the other games. Sure, it's weird to do those all the time IRL. Sure, you can choose to not do them and just play straight shots... but it's fun. Fun with a capital F.Many previous games I've played seemed like an exercise in potluck or else purely strategy with aiming guides being perfect. With this game, some unexpected things do happen, but they've always seemed deserved to me. Hit the cue ball with max force at the wrong time and it might fly off the table. You can also knock other balls of the table.I haven't yet tried online matchmaking, having only played with Steam friends, but I can say that playing with friends is very nicely done. Inviting a friend is very easy, it works with the Steam invite system you've likely already used. During an opponent's shot, you can walk around the table in first person view and see what they're doing, with WSAD and mouse.The game controls excellently. There's no "Hot Shots Power Meter", and getting the power just right is possible, and you can take your time on it, but it's not as precise as just dialing it in. I find it's a great balance between skill and the precision needed for the kinds of trickshots the game sells itself on.The amount of single player content is phenomenal, with new unlocks of ball sets and table decals, as well as pool cues, coming frequently, a little tiny bit at a time. It keeps the game fresh. Whoever hosts an online match can use his unlocks, so it's a fun way of showing how far you've gotten to new players. The single player is so good, I sometimes prefer it to multiplayer, simply to get more "hats and crates."In short - Best pool simulation game I've ever played. Even better than 3D Ultra Cool Pool, if you could count that as a "simulation." (And look up 3D Ultra Cool Pool by Sierra if you want a different kind of pool game, it's very old, but it still has it's charm.)

Posted: January 18, 2014
												For a few quid, you can get this really well put together indie pool game.8 and 9 ball pool await you, and each AI has it own set of challenges. Some of which I have yet to really master and get to grips with.The tutorial section is quite a nice touch, so you're not just dumped in to the game having to figure out things like bank shots etc. Hell, I didn't even know it had a name until I played this game!You can just whack the living bejesus out of the ball, but where's the skill in that??Try bouncing the ball off the top edge of the table to hit the ball you need, or jumping over other balls to get the pot.You've got, as near as I can tell, full control over the ball with spin, lockable power (nice touch!) and cue positioning. You can pull off some really bizarre moves.Overall, this is a really nice game. Presented in a simple to understand format and graphically delicious. The AI characters have some, shall we say, odd traits. . I did giggle a little at Tiffany Bouvier, who'll eat you for breakfast. . Tiffany. Breakfast. . . At least it has a little bit of humour. Music is quite nice, but a little repetative, especially in a long game. But at least you can skip the AI moves quickly. I've been using mouse & keyboard to controll things and it's easy enough. I'll have to give my controller a try and see how I fair.Only tiny tiny gripe I have, is every now and then it crashes. But, the devs are aware, and it should be fixed soon!It would be nice to have a personal table baize as well as the included and DLC. Ah well, maybe the devs could peer in to that as well??Overall, this rates highly in my list and has quickly been added to my favourites.

												For a standard pool game, Pool Nation offers good quality of gameplay and pretty catchy music. It's "theme" is fun and casual. By this, you can expect nice music, colorful graphics, and your basic pool game. So far, I enjoy it despite my low game time showed here. I do not play Pool Nation too often, unless I'm unable to go out to play pool in real-life. Not much to say about Pool Nation. Good quality graphics, enjoyable atmosphere, catchy music, but one thing I don't like is that their controller support is broken in my PC. My Xbox controller are unable to function properly, like some key does different action listed. I'm pretty sure my controller is ok, I'm still using it to play other Steam games that support controller. They have released some hotfix previously, but I'm still unable to get my controller working fine. And this is one of reasons why my playtime is low. I like pool, I like playing it digitally, laid-back on couch and enjoying the game. But without controller, It doesn't feel good for me (This previous sentence is obviously just my opinion.)Last but not least, that is my only problem with the game. Everything else, is pretty good. But still, if I have options to go play pool in real or virtually, I'd be choosing play it real with my friends. Enough said, if you don't have much time to go out and hang on with your friends playing pool, get this game. If you have time to go out, well... Nevertheless, game is ok, and if you have to have this game on your Steam library, go get it.

												I love this game, realistic shooting....jumping, spinning, using the rails, trick shots, everything you would do in an actual game of pool, and the graphics are amazing,  beautiful game. Tons of different table decals, cues, and balls to choose from, different locations to play, some are pretty wild and if you have a good graphics setup you will love it. I only play at night when i am tired, before bed. I love to fire up my media player and play pool, it's a lot of fun ! I own all the DLC and must say that it is really worth the money, i just got the full unlock DLC and now i love the game even more because i can stick to free play, it really didn't unlock everything though, there is a special que that is still locked, and you still have to go through each level in the tournements. Now for the part i don't like. When in free play mode, if you want to use any of the custom options you have to go into a different mode like single player or vs. to choose the customize options for changing tables, balls, ques, and locations, then you have to back out to the main menu then choose free play. There really needs to be a customize button added to the free play menu. Things would so much easier if there were. And it does not save your options after you close the game, you have to go back and choose your options again.Do i recommend this game ? ....HECK YES I DO !

Posted: February 7, 2014
												For Steam's Only (current) Pool Game, Pool Nation sets a high bar for any Billiard-themed game that wants to show up on Steam. The physics for this game are top notch with the ability to perform jump, swerve, bounce and multiball trick shots are but a minute's time and a precice accurate eye, away. And there is nothing more relaxing to me than taking time to set off the perfect shot, and rub it in the Computer's proverbial face.Positives: The Graphics are AMAZING. (I know what you are thinking: "How The [Expletive] could a Pool game have good graphics?!") Well, to put it this way, imagine the shiniest piece of metal to ever grace your eyes. A shine so great you could literally ogle at your perfect image in its reflections. That is how the game looks. It's that good.Negatives: With great graphics, comes great disk space. The ammount of data that was put into making this game look and feel soo good, creates alot of memory. The size of this game is atleast 5x the expected size of what someone would think a Pool game would be, numbers-wise. It is pretty damn big for a 'simple' Pool Game.Grey Areas: The AI. I like to compare the AI in this game slightly similar to the AI in Worms Revolution. How? They both are perfectly accurate when they try, but when they mess up, they mess up HARD. The nicer part about the AI in Pool Nation, though, is that the AI will give you a large break when you first start to play. And the chances of your Computer Counterpart getting a perfect 8 ball streak win against you is almost impossible. But rest assured, there will be no mercy if you can't learn to pocket well. But after touching upon all these needed areas, Pool Nation is definately a must have for cheap, simple, yet enjoyable for many-a-time-gaming. Overall Ranking of games I've played: (9/10 because Left 4 Dead 2 & Kingdom Hearts still have my ties for 10/10 of all time).

Posted: February 8, 2014
												It's got the grahics and the physics that would satisfy any lovers of the pool or snooker game genre. In single player mode I love the tongue in cheek characters you face against in each tournament. The 3 in-match challenges per foe make for a difficult task to those looking at getting every unlock and 100% completion... I like this sort of challenge.Graphically its very smooth with a good use of ambient lighting and color contrast. Theres something of a futuristic style about the in-game themes and pool halls.Another feature I love about this game is the use of trickshots, it can seem alittle exaggerated at times but its always fun to see one played well, or even better playing a beaut yourself. Trick shots without guidelines are where champions leave their mark. As others have said pool nation is a very relaxing experience if you allow it to be, as it's accompanied with a charming soundtrack, sweet visuals and spot on sound effects. It's easy to slump and play...Lastly, the online is where I find the real buzz in pool nation. The community seems friendly so far, though sadly its small in number I believe. (You should join us)For me 5 frames, 8 ball pool, without guide lines is the most enjoyable and of course the most testing in every sense of the word to play online, but its brilliant.9.5/10 - It delivers everything you'd want for this genre

												I see people calling this the best pool game they've ever played. I've played a -lot- of PC (and console) pool games over the years, and this probably is the best one I know of.But! It does have a few quirks. Mainly, it was made to be played with a controller. It can be played with mouse/keyboard but it's a bit clunky. Kind of hard to line up your shot even when you know exactly what you want. I've tried it with a controller and it seems to be much more suited for that, so use one of those if you have one.There are a few other little problems. Most of them are in the UI. It's just not made for someone to navigate it using a mouse. They have released a couple of updates since I last played the game, though, and apparently they have fixed some of the UI problems. I'm eager to go play it again after writing this.All that said, the actual gameplay/physics/etc is phenomenal. That's why it's the best pool game out there.It's well worth $10 dollars, and I would say it'd even be worth the triple-A standard price of $60 without some of the UI problems.As of the time that I'm writing this, it's 70% off ($3) and it's a steal at that price, so go buy it!If you love pool, that is. I certainly do, and would love to play some multiplayer with anyone willing.

Posted: November 11, 2013
												The game is very shiny, the game physics feel like they're very good.   It's got 8-ball, 9-ball, Straight pool, 3 Ball, Rotation, Speed pool and they're going to add more.The AI seems kinda bland, like all the AI opponents are just "I'll take 3 good shots and then screw up on purpose".  The opponents don't talk to you, and heck, you don't even see them walk around the table or anything.  I feel like they could have gone that extra mile to make the opponents in game seem more lively or personable.There's also options for various kinds of customizations.  You have table decals (which range from the mildly distracting to the highly annoying), and decorative balls (all of which are EXTREMELY SHINY!).  You can even customize your pool cue though you'll barely notice that in game.  Finally you can change your game location from a huge room with a view, to a huge room with a view at night, and then to another room without that great of a view...  Again, I feel like they could have made the locations a bit more interesting instead of looking like you're inside a museum.There's an upcoming "Trick shot" mode which may be amusing to play around with, and also snooker is promised as DLC (whether that's worth the extra price or not remains to be seen).The music is a bit too "jazzy" or "technoish" for my tastes but you can turn the volume down.  It would be nice if each location had its own soundtrack (to add more personality to each place) but that could be asking for too much.  It would also be nice if you could tell the game your music folder location and let it play songs from that randomly.All in all though, this is worth the full price, and if it's on sale, buy it now... I've already gotten my money's worth out of it.

												For a standard pool game, Pool Nation offers good quality of gameplay and pretty catchy music. It's "theme" is fun and casual. I do not play Pool Nation too often, unless I'm unable to go out to play pool in real-life. Not much to say about Pool Nation. Good quality graphics, enjoyable atmosphere, catchy music, but one thing I don't like is that their controller support is broken in my PC. My Xbox controller are unable to function properly, like some key does different action listed. I'm pretty sure my controller is ok, I'm still using it to play other Steam games that support controller. They have released some hotfix previously, but I'm still unable to get my controller working fine. And this is one of reasons why my playtime is low. I like pool, I like playing it digitally, laid-back on couch and enjoying the game. But without controller, It doesn't feel good for me (This previous sentence is obviously just my opinion.)Last but not least, that is my only problem with the game. Everything else, is pretty good. But still, if I have options to go play pool in real or virtually, I'd be choosing play it real with my friends. Enough said, if you don't have much time to go out and hang on with your friends playing pool, get this game. If you have time to go out, well... Nevertheless, game is ok, and if you have to have this game on your Steam library, go get it.

Posted: June 21, 2014
												Most realistic physics engine in any cue sport game that I've played. It really is quite impressive, you can pull off just about any shot you can imagine if you have the know how. The AI players start off easy enough for you to get used to the control scheme (which isn't actually that intuitive, but once you get used to it, it's pretty damn good) and the game in general, and they range up to players so hard that if you give them an opportunity, they will clear almost any table. For some, that may be off putting, but it's not too far from reality, a lot of top players will clear almost any table if theyre having a good day.Only issue i have really is that after a while, it gets kinda dull. Caning each AI player one after the other gets too easy after a while, and the only way to lose is to try and get 3 stars for the 3 challenges per match, but providing they don't ask you to do something that actually requires any thought, like a bank or kick shot, you have no excuse not to get all 3 stars.They also try and spice it up with bonus matches of different disciplines of pool, which again is cool for a while, I still haven't mastered them all. I don't really know what to suggest to make it better, it's pretty much as good as I can imagine a pool game getting, barring adding some kind of trick shot challenge, but then again, you may aswell make all shots a trick shot once you're used to the game. 8/10 - A very good time killer

Posted: September 30, 2014
												If you can get it on sale, definitely get it. It's a good pool sim, but I wouldn't say the best. It has some little things that irk me especially having played other pool games like Virtual Pool, and of course real life pool (in which I suck lol).The graphics are beautiful, though at times it may be a little too shiny, like everything is made of chrome. With some balls it's difficult to distinguish between the stripes and the solids due to how the light shines on them at some angles. It also has a tendency for the FPS to shoot up too much if you have a decent gaming rig, so be sure to use VSync or have some kind of frame limiter program like RTSS. The problem with the FPS shooting up is that it makes it harder to aim as how quickly the mouse moves is affected by it. There are no advanced graphics options adjustments except for VSync and anti-aliasing. An option to reduce shininess or even brightness/gamma would've been great.Cue and ball control are fairly good. It may take some getting used to how noticeably slow the rails and the table are if you're coming from other pool games. The speed of the table and whatnot are not adjustable in this game. However, they feel somewhat similar to real life pool tables so that's not a bad thing. The only other odd thing I've noticed is that the side pockets are very open. You can pocket shots into them from angles that you just can't do in real life. Pocket size can't be adjusted either.The UI and interface are very nice. I love the UI sound effects particularly. A minor issue about the interface is that it seems to have been optimized for play with a controller, however due to how slow and inaccurate you are with the controller when playing pool, it's much more comfortable to play with mouse and keyboard anyway. Because it was optimized for controller, the interface options can be a little confusing when playing on mouse and keyboard. Things like a "select" button to go forward/continue and they ask you to press "start" to view your completed challenges. Again it's a minor issue since these are mapped properly by default to certain keys and mouse buttons, but still something they could've addressed.The music is nice, but short and repetitive, and I wish they would've given us more of that. I ended up turning the music off entirely within the first hour and I just play music in the background via iTunes. It's odd, because with a shiny, cool-looking pool game like this you would think they'd have a bit of good music to go with it. Casual games often do.One more issue that bothers me about this game is that you watch your opponent taking the shot as if you're the one at the table taking the shot. This probably won't bother some people, but because of how quickly the AI thinks and how they move the cue, it can be very jarring. I wish they would give us the option to automatically switch to a fixed camera angle when it's the opponent's turn. I like the way Virtual Pool does it, where you're off to the side as if you're physically standing aside while your opponent takes their turn. An option for that would've gone a long way for me.And lastly, I need to comment on the game's AI. It's probably the worst part of it, and you have no choice but to play against it to unlock things like cue stick skins and ball sets. The AI seems to be suffering from a pre-programmed failure algorithm. You can watch even the low level AI make fantastic trick shots or amazing safety placings at the start of their turn, but then they'll suddenly miss on easy shots late in the turn, often on the last ball itself. After having played hundreds of matches against the AI, it feels like a pre-determined failure chance to make sure the player gets a chance at the table. It gets so bad that sometimes you'll miss on the 9-ball and it rattles in the pocket, and it'd go in if anybody sneezes, yet the AI somehow misses it too. As a testament to how rushed the AI feels, the AI never changes its shot (such as moving the ball or changing the angle at least) on the break. It's always dead center, and therefore you end up with very similar shot options all the time after the AI's break. I don't think that's cool. A good AI should make it feel like you're playing against humans too, again something that Virtual Pool did much better.Overall it's just another pool game. A good one, but it could definitely be better. Well worth the money if you get it on sale, and a great gift to give a friend if you know they're into this kind of game too. Then you can play each other online.

Posted: September 30, 2014
												There's a lot of good, free pool games on websites for you to play, so why should you even care about Pool Nation? Because if you like pool-games you'll have to buy a waterproof computer you really should care about it!Visually it's quite the looker... I'm not gonna go into the whole "shiny balls" discussion, but it is a good looking game. The physics are also spot on, and you can have a little bit more of finesse in your shots in comparison to most free web-based pool-games. There are a handful of game modes including your classics like 8ball and 9ball. The only thing missing is snooker, which isn't a pool-game by itself but it would've been fun to have it included.The single player campaign is fun with "missions" for every match that'll give you bonuses and unlocks if you manage to achieve them. Also, of course, there's online multiplayer.The only negative thing I can come to think of is that the port (it was originally released on console) didn't really manage to get the "select ball and pocket"-mechanic to work with a mouse-and-keyboard-setup which feels kinda strange since it should be easier with a mouse than with a controller. You'll get past that but at first it gets really frustrating if you want to pocket the ball in another pocket than what the game assumes.With that said there's just one question you need to ask yourself; do I want to play pool on my computer? If the answer is "yes" then Pool Nation is the game for you. If the answer is "no"... go get that waterproof PC.
