Posted: November 22, 2014
												It was really well done with some of the smoothest ball mechanics I've seen to date, though not with some flaws. (Edit online play summary) Well as promised once I'm editing in my take on online admittedly I only played one game but it was fun and decent, the best thing is I wasn't put on some shot clock and forced to shoot within a specific time frame (that's fine if it's a part of the game mechanic/style aka like a time attack or rush but in my personal opinion giving someone a shot clock in stanard play pool is just silly as it's not something to be rushed, especially if it's a difficult one that requires serious percision) which personaly always annoys me and has ruined my last half dozen or so "online pool game experiences. Only gripe so far is that the power setting is a bit off or to be blunt it's not too realistic as max unless preforming a jump shot will almost always result in the ball going off the table which in my experience as an actual casual pool player rarely happens even with a full strength hit, also along those lines tagging a ball slightly doesn't always provide the moment it should making trick multishots, combinations, and the always fun clip shots extra difficult. And lastly this is just a pet peeve due to the fact that video game based pool games always lack a degree of visual depth so you kind of need an aim marker for precise shots which in real life pool you can make just with your own judgement/imagination and this one while highly decent lacks the key feature of projecting a line for each ball struck and instead focuses on the cue and the first ball it hits. In short for a pool game it's good for what it is, I'd say a 7/10 and if you enjoy pool and want a game that does a fairly good job of simulating it then this is a definite must while on sale, though honestly I'd never pay more than $5 for it.

Posted: November 22, 2014
												Pool Nation is a your run-of-the-mill billiards with impressive physics and graphics.I haven't played pool since I was at a christmas party with my relatives back around 2007, and playing this type of game brought back some nostalgia for me.This was my first in a very long time playing a billiards video game, and I'm talking a looong time...like around when Sega Genesis was still new and Sonic 3 hasn't even come out. I think I was only...what, five years old during the time?In any case, the controls took some getting used to, but after about 10 minutes into playing "9 Ball", everything felt natural.The camera angles give a nice sense of realism, and if adjusted correctly, you feel as if you're holding the pool stick yourself and hitting the target...with psychic eyes in seeing guidelines.The physics in this game felt just right for me, where like real pool, speed and precision matter when banking shots, as well as how you plan to hit the ball, such as curving and hopping.The graphics added a nice sense of realism to the game, and the crisp clear look on each ball gave the game a nice type of brilliance. The only thing I question is that every ball has a reflection, which is very awkward to me, since I know actual billiard balls aren't that reflective in real life. But I'm being anal at that point, and you might as well add scratches to the balls and pool table, and make the atmosphere bleak.Yeah, that's real pool right there, but I'm digressing at this point.Overall, with the different types of modes in the game, and the option to play with a friend or online, this game is pretty solid, and I would recommend this game to any of my friends that want to play a billiards game without the need of♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off pool owners for scratching up the leather.

Posted: November 26, 2014
												The most beautiful pool game you will ever see.There is so much detail, you can see the reflection of the room in the balls when it closes up, it is amazing. Worth purchasing as eye candy alone.But that's not all, the game offers a TON of content to boot. Dozens of decals, cues, ball sets, single player tournaments, multiplayer, this game has hours upon hours of fun.My only gripe with it is that steam achievements aren't working properly for some reason. Other than that, I can recommend it to anyone.

Posted: September 30, 2014
												If you can get it on sale, definitely get it. It's a good pool sim, but I wouldn't say the best. It has some little things that irk me especially having played other pool games like Virtual Pool, and of course real life pool (in which I suck lol).The graphics are beautiful, though at times it may be a little too shiny, like everything is made of chrome. With some balls it's difficult to distinguish between the stripes and the solids due to how the light shines on them at some angles. It also has a tendency for the FPS to shoot up too much if you have a decent gaming rig, so be sure to use VSync or have some kind of frame limiter program like RTSS. The problem with the FPS shooting up is that it makes it harder to aim as how quickly the mouse moves is affected by it. There are no advanced graphics options adjustments except for VSync and anti-aliasing. An option to reduce shininess or even brightness/gamma would've been great.Cue and ball control are fairly good. It may take some getting used to how noticeably slow the rails and the table are if you're coming from other pool games. The speed of the table and whatnot are not adjustable in this game. However, they feel somewhat similar to real life pool tables so that's not a bad thing. The only other odd thing I've noticed is that the side pockets are very open. You can pocket shots into them from angles that you just can't do in real life. Pocket size can't be adjusted either.The UI and interface are very nice. I love the UI sound effects particularly. A minor issue about the interface is that it seems to have been optimized for play with a controller, however due to how slow and inaccurate you are with the controller when playing pool, it's much more comfortable to play with mouse and keyboard anyway. Because it was optimized for controller, the interface options can be a little confusing when playing on mouse and keyboard. Things like a "select" button to go forward/continue and they ask you to press "start" to view your completed challenges. Again it's a minor issue since these are mapped properly by default to certain keys and mouse buttons, but still something they could've addressed.The music is nice, but short and repetitive, and I wish they would've given us more of that. I ended up turning the music off entirely within the first hour and I just play music in the background via iTunes. It's odd, because with a shiny, cool-looking pool game like this you would think they'd have a bit of good music to go with it. Casual games often do.One more issue that bothers me about this game is that you watch your opponent taking the shot as if you're the one at the table taking the shot. This probably won't bother some people, but because of how quickly the AI thinks and how they move the cue, it can be very jarring. I wish they would give us the option to automatically switch to a fixed camera angle when it's the opponent's turn. I like the way Virtual Pool does it, where you're off to the side as if you're physically standing aside while your opponent takes their turn. An option for that would've gone a long way for me.And lastly, I need to comment on the game's AI. It's probably the worst part of it, and you have no choice but to play against it to unlock things like cue stick skins and ball sets. The AI seems to be suffering from a pre-programmed failure algorithm. You can watch even the low level AI make fantastic trick shots or amazing safety placings at the start of their turn, but then they'll suddenly miss on easy shots late in the turn, often on the last ball itself. After having played hundreds of matches against the AI, it feels like a pre-determined failure chance to make sure the player gets a chance at the table. It gets so bad that sometimes you'll miss on the 9-ball and it rattles in the pocket, and it'd go in if anybody sneezes, yet the AI somehow misses it too. As a testament to how rushed the AI feels, the AI never changes its shot (such as moving the ball or changing the angle at least) on the break. It's always dead center, and therefore you end up with very similar shot options all the time after the AI's break. I don't think that's cool. A good AI should make it feel like you're playing against humans too, again something that Virtual Pool did much better.Overall it's just another pool game. A good one, but it could definitely be better. Well worth the money if you get it on sale, and a great gift to give a friend if you know they're into this kind of game too. Then you can play each other online.

Posted: October 3, 2014
												Realistic game of pool, sounds great and the physics are nice.There's different camera views, you have a top down mode for when you need to look at the entire table for extreme accuracy, and a first-person? (not sure what to call it) mode and it feels great to play in, like you're really at a pool table playing.They even have slow-mo cams that zoom in to the ball when you've shot one in (only happens once in a while so it's not annoying and you can skip it if you want by pressing the button for skipping; you can even choose to skip the turns the npc takes when you want to play against them).Singleplayer has different modes, and you can play against npcs in several types of games (while sometimes unlocking different designs for the cue, ball, or the table as rewards for certain things).There's 'free mode' where you can just play by yourself without a limit (if you just want to shoot while relaxing or try out certain moves).There's also an endurance mode, which is like free mode (the by yourself without npc aspect), but is timed or rather the goal is to shoot as many balls in as you can, as fast and accurate as you can before too many extra balls get added to the table.And they have a tutorial mode where you can learn how to play and learn advanced tricks.You can turn the guiding 'lines' completely off, for people who want to play real-world style;they're just like training wheels and you can choose to use them or not, and you can also choose to have the lines, but have different types, if you want.The npcs aren't perfect shots, but they're not terrible either, and sometimes they'll miss after perfectly shooting 4-ball in a row or something, for example;it's a bit random, kinda like a real person might miss, even if they're good.There's plenty of content to play, challenges in the game that unlock bonus rounds, new areas and npc characters, or reward you with a design for the cue, ball, or table, that you can use to play with.And of course there's still the steam achievements.Or you can try to master the advanced tricks from the tutorial and try them in free mode and then later against npcs.You can also repeat maps you've played already (when you unlock something it gets unlocked for permanent use).Some games I regret buying, but this is definitely not one of them.If you like pool games, this is a nice one to have

There are a handful of game modes including your classics like 8ball and 9ball. The only thing missing is snooker, which isn't a pool-game by itself but it would've been fun to have it included.The single player campaign is fun with "missions" for every match that'll give you bonuses and unlocks if you manage to achieve them. Also, of course, there's online multiplayer.The only negative thing I can come to think of is that the port (it was originally released on console) didn't really manage to get the "select ball and pocket"-mechanic to work with a mouse-and-keyboard-setup which feels kinda strange since it should be easier with a mouse than with a controller. You'll get past that but at first it gets really frustrating if you want to pocket the ball in another pocket than what the game assumes.With that said there's just one question you need to ask yourself; do I want to play pool on my computer? If the answer is "yes" then Pool Nation is the game for you. If the answer is "no"... go get that waterproof PC.

There are only lots of lobbies for 2 players only to startthe match, so you need search through lobbies or invite friends. And there is no stuck on lobby.. Posted: July 5, 2014
												If you're looking for a pool game on Steam, look no further. This is the most graphically, physically, and stylistically impressive pool game I've ever played, and I've been playing them for almost my whole life (going all the way back to Side Pocket on the NES.) The balls, rails and pockets behave just as they would on a real pool table. And there are a bunch of different ways to play, thanks to many diverse mini-games. There's a great training mode too, so even anyone who has never played pool before can pull off trick shots like a master. There's nothing more satisfying than seeing your perfectly aimed jump shot in slow motion as it knocks the target ball in the pocket. It's fun, it's calming, it's everything a great pool game should be. And I recommend it.

Posted: December 6, 2014
												Pool Nation is a billiards game with many arcade features, such as unlocking custom items, playing against different NPC players until you reach the boss of each stage, scoring the highest number of points (global ranking) and also completing challenges to play at the bonus rounds The soundtrack is awesome, the graphics are beautiful and the game itself is a lot of fun, since it allows you to make some really unique shots. Besides that, it also has trading cards and its price is quite affordable, so I definitely recommend it.

Posted: February 27, 2014
												5/10Due to the recent craze of 8 ball pool on android I decided to give this a go from the new weekly bundle and I have to say it's what I expected it to be when I first saw it on steam.The controls are pretty hard to get the hang of and the game rules themselves are pretty unfamiliar to me; this isn't the kind of pool I'm used to and to be honest this is easier. Despite it being easier the game has a tendancy to not let me progress even though I get massive wins.Other than that there isn't much choice for pool games which is why I gave this a 5/10 / yes rating. The game could do with some nice progression like the android game, especially since the android game mentioned earlier is free.Suggestions: Allowing you to use an avatar (play as your character, no development though as that makes the game unfair), chips, betting, money, homes / clubs to spend your winnings, cues to buy etc and the list goes on.

I used to play 9 ball about 15 hours a week for years... so i have a decent idea. What else can you really ask for? Posted: December 31, 2015
												It's the most enjoyable simulator for pool that I've played on steam. My favorite pool game, so far, has been Virtual Pool 4. This game is a bit more arcadey and social driven than that game, but it is still really enjoyable for someone that is into playing pool.In short:+ Good graphics compared to other pool games+ Entertaining game modes+ Multiplayer+ Unlockables+ Trick shots+ Social content+ Creatable content+ Pretty much endless replayability since it is pool+ Easy for a beginner trying to get into a pool sim- Sometimes a bit buggy when trying to move or shoot with the mouse- A little bit arcadey for pool especially when comparing physics to real life or even VP4, but forgiveable since it isn't trying to actually be a hardcore sim- Sometimes a bit more focused on everything else except for the actual game of pool itselfOverall, it's a great game for the price. I'd definitely would recommend this to a friend interested in pool sims.

Posted: April 30, 2014
												Almost as good as Super Monkey Ball Billiards. Almost.The gameplay is pretty smooth. Not too many crazy bugs or anything like that. The UI could use a whole lot of work, though. Navigating the menus is a slight challenge which should not be the case at all. Other than those two elements, the game plays very well (although I would still choose to play a different billiards game over this one).6/10

Posted: December 15, 2016
												Pool Nation resides in a niche genre that anyone interested knows generally what to expect. Like most people, I'm mainly concerned with a pool game feeling right. That means there must be a finely tuned physics engine in place to mimic physical actions and reactions, whether it be a simple or advanced system. Pool Nation absolutely meets this requirement and then some. It provide the player with a very nicely crafted physics system to experience billiards virtually. Of course, the actual game trumps experiencing it virtually, but the imitation is overall convincing and worthwhile. Not only is the core game well constructed, but the development team made sure to provide the extras that keeps players interested. It's definitely worth the buy if you're looking for a solid pool game, especially considering its fair sale price.

Posted: November 11, 2013
												The game is very shiny, the game physics feel like they're very good.   It's got 8-ball, 9-ball, Straight pool, 3 Ball, Rotation, Speed pool and they're going to add more.The AI seems kinda bland, like all the AI opponents are just "I'll take 3 good shots and then screw up on purpose".  The opponents don't talk to you, and heck, you don't even see them walk around the table or anything.  I feel like they could have gone that extra mile to make the opponents in game seem more lively or personable.There's also options for various kinds of customizations.  You have table decals (which range from the mildly distracting to the highly annoying), and decorative balls (all of which are EXTREMELY SHINY!).  You can even customize your pool cue though you'll barely notice that in game.  Finally you can change your game location from a huge room with a view, to a huge room with a view at night, and then to another room without that great of a view...  Again, I feel like they could have made the locations a bit more interesting instead of looking like you're inside a museum.There's an upcoming "Trick shot" mode which may be amusing to play around with, and also snooker is promised as DLC (whether that's worth the extra price or not remains to be seen).The music is a bit too "jazzy" or "technoish" for my tastes but you can turn the volume down.  It would be nice if each location had its own soundtrack (to add more personality to each place) but that could be asking for too much.  It would also be nice if you could tell the game your music folder location and let it play songs from that randomly.All in all though, this is worth the full price, and if it's on sale, buy it now... I've already gotten my money's worth out of it.

 Recommendation  Recommended  Base Game Score  B+  Style  Simulation/Sports/Casual  Recommendation Summary  Pool Nation is a game basically involving you playing pool. The game itself has good graphics, and a good UI. I am not experienced with pool simulations, but this game is what I imagine to be the top tier video game for pool simulation. If you are not a pool player, such as myself, then you will still enjoy this game, whether actively engaged, or passively listening to something else. It is a great little game that is worth taking a look at if you are interested. I recommend this game for really anyone.

AMAZING!
